entry.title: There Is No Antimemetics Division by qntm
entry.summary: Have you ever walked into a room and forgotten why you entered?
entry.content:
Have you ever walked into a room and forgotten why you entered?

I had something to clever to say about this book – at least, I think I did. It was something about memory, or maybe forgetting? But now that I sit down to write, the specifics slip away. Weird.

I’m pretty sure there was a secretive government department involved, but I can’t for the life of me remember what they were responsible for. Something about ideas that couldn’t be remembered? I guess that’s plausible enough. Neal Stephenson explores viral ideas – memes – in Snow Crash, so I suppose I can accept the inversion of that concept. We might as well call that an antimeme . Or, for those familiar with Doctor Who , think of the Silence – aliens who fade from memory as soon as they’re out of sight. Funny, my head is starting to hurt. Perhaps I should discuss the writing style instead.

The author shows heaps of raw talent and creativity, reminiscent of PK Dick in both theme and style. There’s the reality distortion of Ubik and A Scanner Darkly , and the unreliable memory from We Can Remember it for You Wholesale . Like with PKD, the prose can be a bit forced, and not all narrative threads are fully resolved. The author wavers between treating antimemes conceptually, like in Snow Crash , or personifying them, like in Doctor Who, mostly leaning towards the latter. This somewhat reduces the intellectual depth of the novel. By personifying antimemes, the author becomes over-reliant on gore and grotesquerie. One sees a similar transition between the early Lovecraft, whose gothic works (The Gothic Tales of H. P. Lovecraft) draw heavily on grotesque horror, and the late Lovecraft, for whom terror dwells in the nameless implicit rather than the grotesque explicit. Lovecraft himself had an interesting relationship with memory and forgetfulness, famously haunted by vivid nightmares that inspired his stories but faded quickly on waking. This was probably a case of undiagnosed sleep paralysis, a condition experienced by about 7.6% of the general population, which can occur during the transition between the REM sleep stage and wakefulness as the brain becomes conscious while the muscles remaind paralysed. Wait, why do I feel like I’ve been pushed onto a tangent.

Anyway, I’m left with the unsettling sense that I’ve read something important – viscerally new, terrifying, and engaging. A work of genuine talent from a rising author who hopefully has many more books ahead.

Have you ever walked into a room and forgotten why you entered?

entry.title: Willpower by Roy Baumeister, John Tierney
entry.summary: Willpower is a finite resource, but it can be strengthened over time.
entry.content:
Early in the summer, something strange happened to me. Though I didn’t recognise it at the time, I had lost much of my willpower. This was worrying, as I used to pride myself on having an iron will. I could make myself go to the gym when tired, spend long hours in deep focus, and invest my time with a low discount rate – putting in considerable up-front effort for long-term payoffs. Then, in summer, I noticed that I had become floppy, lazy, and indecisive; the house was always messy, and my task backlog was growing by the day. An unsustainable situation, indeed. This book helped me diagnose what had happened.

Until fairly recently, the concept of willpower was explored more in the realm of poetry and biography than in serious psychological research – another classic case of science shying away from ideas that are hard to define, even when important and deserving of study. Roy Baumeister was among the first psychologists to take willpower seriously, and this book, written with John Tierney, summarises years of his research.

The core thesis is that willpower is very much like a muscle. On any given day, we have a finite amount that gets depleted as we expend it. But over time, through training, we can improve its capacity and durability. Once willpower is drained (technically, once we enter a state of ego depletion ), we struggle to exert ourselves mentally and physically, lose emotional regulation, make impulsive decisions, and crave sweet foods.

This partially explained the “what” of my predicament: by not recognising my reduced willpower, I failed to intervene in the vicious cycle and stopped practising habits that build and maintain willpower. The unwashed dishes and untidy desk were more important than I had realised. A loss of willpower has many ugly downstream consequences: work performance declines, fitness slips, and even social connections suffer as we stop reaching out to friends. But what started this downward spiral? For this, we must turn to the second part of the book’s thesis.

Baumeister found that decision-making heavily depletes willpower resources. This claim seems so intuitive that you might think it obvious. But it’s distinct from the earlier observation that reduced willpower impairs decision-making. There’s a tight, bidirectional relationship that I really don’t think is obvious. In Baumeister’s experiments, participants who made many decisions, even about trivial things like shopping, gave up more easily on a grip strength test (a classic measure of ego depletion). Car salespeople know this phenomenon well: by presenting many options initially, customers become more likely to accept the default option later.

This was the definitive explanation for me. Early summer marked the end of my first six months as a risk-taking trader (“portfolio manager”). The job requires constant decision-making. Every news item, every tick of the chart implicitly demands a choice: should I adjust my positions or do nothing? After long trading days, I would return home utterly spent. Everything felt “purple.” I was more emotional, less willing to make decisions (even about simple things like what to order for dinner), more comfort-seeking, and less resilient to cravings. I stopped maintaining disciplined habits, perpetuating the cycle.

It is true that the book is poorly written. Chapters are long and disorganised; studies are repeated. If it were half as long and included chapter summaries, it could easily merit five stars. But that hardly matters. The two-part recognition – that my willpower had been diminished and that the reduction was due to decision-making – has markedly changed how I approach life. I’ve made it a priority to cultivate disciplined habits, like keeping the house tidy and being much stricter with time allocation. I’ve become more conscious about sugar intake, improved my diet, and created systems at work to reduce the number of decisions I have to make, conserving mental capital. I’ve added barriers to prevent instant dopamine hits from electronic devices (see Stolen Focus and Hooked for details on how apps tap into our dopamine circuits). I was particularly inspired by the book’s anecdotes about Henry Morton Stanley, who, in the midst of his disastrous exploration into central Africa to find Livingstone – in which more than half of his men perished – he would find time to shave every day. My simple version of that: every day since finishing the book, I’ve made my bed.

Key ideas

  • Core thesis:
    • Two key traits predict positive outcomes: intelligence and self-control.
    • Willpower is a muscle: using it depletes it, but can be strengthened over time
    • Decision-making draws from the same well.
    • Ego depletion: when we exert willpower (including by decision-making), we reduce our capacity to regulate thoughts, feelings and actions. All feelings and reactions become stronger
    • Rebuild willpower by: completing goals you’ve set, exercising discipline (e.g. staying tidy) timeboxing.
    • Tactics like positive procrastination to deal with temptations.
    • Willpower is correlated across areas of life
    • Ego depletion consumes glucose – that’s why we start craving sweets
  • Categories of willpower use:
    • Controlling thoughts, e.g. Trying to ignore something
    • Control of emotions (“affect regulation”)
    • Impulse control: resisting temptations
    • Performance control: focusing your energy on a task, managing time, persevering.
  • Goal setting:
    • One big project at a time, since we only have finite willpower resources.
    • People who think more about goals ruminate more and make less progress. Conflicting goals lead to a lot unhappiness!
    • “Next action” (GTD): your todo list should have specific next actions.
    • Zeigarnik effect: uncompleted tasks take up mindshare. You have to write down a quick plan
  • Willpower can be strengthened with disciplined habits:
    • E.g. students who improved their posture had better outcomes
    • Improve discipline by having a clean environment and daily personal cleanliness routines, e.g. Henry Stanley, during the disastrous exploration of central Africa, would shave every day.
    • Writers who make a daily writing habit tend to do better than “binge writers”
    • Religious activity is associated with better self-control and also many positive habits.
  • Experiments:
    • Subjects watch a sad movie. Some told to either suppress emotions or be extra expressive. Then grip duration is tested. Both groups that controlled their emotional reactions had less willpower.
    • Monkeys can only project 20 minutes into the future – enough time to let the alpha male eat. If they are given food once a day, they don’t save any.
  • Self-esteem vs self-control in children:
    • Parents should instill self-control rather than self-esteem.
    • In experiments where self-esteem is boosted, outcomes (grades) are worse.
    • Self-esteem does increase initiative, and it provides a bank of positive emotions which can help in difficult times.
    • Success causes self-esteem rather than vice versa
    • Broad increases in narcissism may be related to the self-esteem movement.
    • Children should be punished with prompt, calm, and consistent reprimands. Severity doesn’t help.
  • Dieting:
    • Dieting generally counterproductive. When people fail to meet their target, they say “what the hell” and eat in excess.
    • Sweet food particularly hard to resist because self-control depletes glucose
  • Specific tips on diet:
    • Postpone pleasure. Tell yourself you can have it later. This satisfies the craving somewhat. If craving sugar, eat something with low GI first. This helps repopulate the glucose
    • Keep unhealthy food out of sight, so that you don’t need to expend willpower to avoid it.
    • Simple precommitments: e.g. brushing teeth earlier.
    • Measurement is good: research shows that people in general are not fazed by the volatility.

Highlights

Core premise

willpower, like a muscle, becomes fatigued from overuse but can also be strengthened over the long term through exercise. (loc 80)

• • •

people with good self-control mainly use it not for rescue in emergencies but rather to develop effective habits and routines in school and at work. The results of these habits and routines were demonstrated in yet another recent set of studies, in the United States, showing that people with high self-control consistently report less stress in their lives. They use their self-control not to get through crises but to avoid them. (loc 3464)

• • •

Your supply of willpower is limited, and you use the same resource for many different things. (loc 3530)

• • •

Virtually no one has a gut-level sense of just how tiring it is to decide. Choosing what to have for dinner, where to go on vacation, whom to hire, how much to spend—these all take willpower. Even hypothetical decisions deplete energy. After making some tough decisions, remember that your self-control is going to be weakened. Remember, too, that what matters is the exertion, not the outcome. If you struggle with temptation and then give in, you’re still depleted because you struggled. (loc 3540)

• • •

When you’re budgeting your time, don’t give drudgery more than its necessary share. Remember Parkinson’s Law: Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion. Set a firm time limit for tedious tasks. “Clean out basement” or “Reorganize closets” could take up the whole day—if you ever got around to it, which you won’t because you don’t want to lose a day of your life to something so mundane. But if you set a clear limit of one or two hours, you might get something done this Saturday (loc 3600)

• • •

Another simple old-fashioned way to boost your willpower is to expend a little of it on neatness. As we described in chapter 7, people exert less self-control after seeing a messy desk than after seeing a clean desk, or when using a sloppy rather than a neat and wellorganized Web site. You may not care about whether your bed is made and your desk is clean, but these environmental cues subtly influence your brain and your behavior, making it ultimately less of a strain to maintain self-discipline. (loc 3651)

• • •

Procrastination is usually a vice, but occasionally—very occasionally—there is such a thing as positive procrastination. In the previous chapter we discussed experiments showing that people tempted by chocolate managed to avoid it by telling themselves they’d eat it some other time—a postponement strategy that worked better than trying to deny themselves altogether. This “I’ll have it later” trick can work for other temptations, too. If a TV show is keeping you from getting back to work, record it and tell yourself you’ll finish watching it later. (loc 3661)

• • •

Monitoring is crucial for any kind of plan you make—and it can even work if you don’t make a plan at all. (loc 3707)

• • •

When you set a goal, set a reward for reaching it—and then don’t stiff yourself. If you just use willpower to deny yourself things, it becomes a grim, thankless form of defense. But when you use it to gain something, you can wring pleasure out of the dreariest tasks. (loc 3721)

• • •
Ego depletion

Freud, who theorized that the self depended on mental activities involving the transfer of energy. But Freud’s energy model of the self was generally ignored by subsequent researchers. (loc 135)

• • •

“ego depletion,” Baumeister’s term for describing people’s diminished capacity to regulate their thoughts, feelings, and actions. People can sometimes overcome mental fatigue, but Baumeister found that if they had used up energy by exerting willpower (or by making decisions, another form of ego depletion that we’ll discuss later), they would eventually succumb. […]

while depleted persons (once again) didn’t show any single telltale emotion, they did react more strongly to all kinds of things. A sad movie made them extra sad. Joyous pictures made them happier, and disturbing pictures made them more frightened and upset. Ice-cold water felt more painful to them than it did to people who were not ego-depleted. Desires intensified along with feelings. (loc 479)

• • •

ego depletion causes a slowdown in the anterior cingulate cortex, the brain area that’s crucial to self-control. As the brain slows down and its error-detection ability deteriorates, people have trouble controlling their reactions.

…

There’s no obvious “feeling” of depletion. Hence you need to watch yourself for subtle, easily misinterpreted signs. Do things seem to bother you more than they should? Has the volume somehow been turned up on your life so that things are felt more strongly than usual? Is it suddenly hard to make up your mind about even simple things? Are you more than usually reluctant to make a decision or exert yourself mentally or physically? If you notice such feelings, then reflect on the last few hours and see if it seems likely that you have depleted your willpower. If so, try to conserve what’s left while anticipating the effects on your behavior. (loc 3550)

• • •

“Closing a door on an option is experienced as a loss, and people are willing to pay a price to avoid the emotion of loss,” Ariely says. Sometimes that makes sense, but too often we’re so eager to keep options open that we don’t see the long-term price that we’re paying—or that others are paying. When you won’t settle for less than a perfect mate, you end up with no one. (loc 1491)

Decision making is stressful

• • •

When your willpower is low, you’re less able to make these trade-offs. You become what researchers call a “cognitive miser,” hoarding your energy by avoiding compromises. You’re liable to look at only one dimension, like price: Just give me the cheapest. (loc 1504)

• • •
Glucose

When a psychiatrist testifying for the defense cited White’s consumption of Twinkies and other junk food in the days before the murders, journalists mocked White for trying to excuse himself with a “Twinkie defense.” In fact, White’s chief defense wasn’t based on the argument that the Twinkies turned him murderous by causing his blood-sugar levels to quickly spike and then crash. His attorneys argued that he deserved mercy because he suffered from “diminished capacity” due to severe depression, and they presented his junk-food consumption (along with other changes in habits) as evidence of his depression, (loc 681)

• • •

One study found below-average glucose levels in 90 percent of the juvenile delinquents recently taken into custody. Other studies reported that people with hypoglycemia were more likely to be convicted of a wide variety of offenses: traffic violations, public profanity, shoplifting, destruction of property, exhibitionism, public masturbation, embezzlement, arson, spouse abuse, and child abuse. (loc 688)

• • •

The effects of the drinks showed up clearly in a study of aggression among people playing a computer game. At first, the game seemed reasonable, but it soon became impossibly difficult. Everyone got frustrated as the game went on, but the one who got a sugar-filled drink managed to grumble quietly and keep playing. The others started cursing aloud and banging the computer. (loc 736)

• • •

As the body uses glucose during self-control, it starts to crave sweet things to eat—which is bad news for people hoping to use their self-control to avoid sweets. When people have more demands for self-control in their daily lives, their hunger for sweets increases. It’s not a simple matter of wanting all food more—they seem to be specifically hungry for sweets. In the lab, students who have just performed a self-control task eat more sweet snacks but not other (salty) snacks. (loc 771)

• • •

PMS, like hypoglycemia and diabetes, makes a conveniently clear-cut example of what happens when the body is short of glucose—and everyone, male or female, diabetic or nondiabetic, runs low on glucose at times (loc 851)

• • •

To maintain steady self-control, you’re better off eating foods with a low glycemic index: most vegetables, nuts (like peanuts and cashews), many raw fruits (like apples, blueberries, and pears), cheese, fish, meat, olive oil, and other “good” fats. (loc 885)

• • •
Goal setting

Focus on one project at a time. If you set more than one self-improvement goal, you may succeed for a while by drawing on reserves to power through, but that just leaves you more depleted and more prone to serious mistakes later. When people have to make a big change in their lives, their efforts are undermined if they are trying to make other changes as well. (loc 588)

• • •

The result of conflicting goals is unhappiness instead of action, (loc 988)

see Hamlet.

• • •

It might seem that people who think more about their goals would also take more steps to reach them, but instead they replace action with rumination. The researchers found that people with clear, unconflicting goals tended to forge ahead and make progress, but the rest were so busy worrying that they got stuck. (loc 996)

• • •

people with conflicting goals reported fewer positive emotions, more negative emotions, and more depression and anxiety. They had more psychosomatic complaints and symptoms. Even just plain physical sickness, measured both by the number of visits to the doctor and by the number of self-reported illnesses over the course of a year, was higher among the people with conflicting goals. The more the goals conflicted, the more the people got stuck, and the more unhappy and unhealthy they became. (loc 999)

• • •

The group with the proximal goals outperformed everyone else when the program was over and competence was tested. They succeeded, apparently, because meeting these daily goals gradually built their confidence and self-efficacy. With their focus on a specific goal for each session, they learned better and faster than the others. (loc 1041)

Something to be said about greedy optimisation

• • •

The monthly planning group did the best, in terms of improvements in study habits and attitudes. Among the weaker students (though not among the good ones), monthly planning led to much bigger improvements in grades than did the daily planning. Monthly planners also kept it up much longer than the daily planners, and the continued planning thus was more likely to carry over into their work after the program ended. (loc 1067)

• • •

Those who’d written about unfulfilled tasks had more trouble keeping their minds focused on the novel—unless they’d made a specific plan to complete the task, in which case they reported relatively little mind wandering and scored quite well on the reading comprehension test. Even though they hadn’t finished the task or made any palpable progress, the simple act of making a plan had cleared their minds and eliminated the Zeigarnik effect. (loc 1230)

• • •
Disciplined habits

By overriding their habit of slouching, the students strengthened their willpower and did better at tasks that had nothing to do with posture. The improvement was most pronounced among the students who had followed the advice most diligently (as measured by the daily logs the students kept of how often they’d forced themselves to sit up or stand up straight). (loc 1909)

• • •

Exercising self-control in one area seemed to improve all areas of life. (loc 1976)

…

But as of this morning, you’re not dead yet. There’s no food in camp, but at least you’re alive. Now that you’ve arisen and taken care of nature’s first call of the morning, what’s the next thing to do? For Stanley, this was an easy decision: shave. As one of his servants in England would later recall: “He had often told me that, on his various expeditions, he had made it a rule, always to shave carefully. In the Great Forest, in ‘Starvation Camp,’ on the mornings of battle, he had never neglected this custom, however great the difficulty; he told me he had often shaved with cold water, or with blunt razors.” (loc 2250)

Murakami: in every shave lies a philosophy

• • •

Stanley’s belief in the link between external order and inner self-discipline has been confirmed recently in some remarkable studies. In one experiment, a group of participants answered questions sitting in a nice neat laboratory room, while others sat in the kind of place that inspires parents to shout, “Clean up your room!” The people in the messy room scored lower in self-control on many measures, such as being unwilling to wait a week for a larger sum of money as opposed to taking a smaller sum right away. (loc 2262)

• • •

The page-a-day folks had done well and generally gotten tenure. The so-called “binge writers” fared far less well, and many had had their careers cut short. The clear implication was that the best advice for young writers and aspiring professors is: Write every day. Use your self-control to form a daily habit, and you’ll produce more with less effort in the long run. (loc 2303)

• • •

If you’re in a religious congregation and ask God for longer life, you are likely to get it. It doesn’t even seem to matter which god you ask. Any sort of religious activity increases your longevity,

[…]

Religious people are less likely than others to develop unhealthy habits, like getting drunk, engaging in risky sex, taking illicit drugs, and smoking cigarettes. They’re more likely to wear seat belts, visit a dentist, and take vitamins. They have better social support, and their faith helps them cope psychologically with misfortunes. And they have better self-control, (loc 2594)

• • •
Parenting

The strongest evidence yet was published in 2010. In a painstaking long-term study, much larger and more thorough than anything done previously, an international team of researchers tracked one thousand children in New Zealand from birth until the age of thirty-two. Each child’s self-control was rated in a variety of ways (through observations by researchers as well as in reports of problems from parents, teachers, and the children themselves). This produced an especially reliable measure of children’s self-control, and the researchers were able to check it against an extraordinarily wide array of outcomes through adolescence and into adulthood. The children with high self-control grew up into adults who had better physical health, including lower rates of obesity, fewer sexually transmitted diseases, and even healthier teeth. (Apparently, good self-control includes brushing and flossing.) (loc 236)

• • •

Yes, students with higher self-esteem did have higher grades. But which came first? Did students’ self-esteem lead to good grades, or did good grades lead to self-esteem? It turned out that grades in tenth grade predicted self-esteem in twelfth grade, but self-esteem in tenth grade failed to predict grades in twelfth grade. Thus, it seemed, the grades came first, and the self-esteem came afterward. (loc 2757)

• • •

In another carefully controlled study, Donald Forsyth tried boosting the self-esteem of some of the students in his psychology class at Virginia Commonwealth University. He randomly assigned some students who got a C grade or worse on the midterm to receive a weekly message boosting their self-esteem, and some students with similar grades to get a neutral weekly message. The weekly pep talks presumably helped the students feel better about themselves, but it didn’t help their grades—quite to the contrary. When they took the final exam, not only did they do worse than the control group but their grades were even lower than what they’d gotten on the midterm. Their average score dropped from 59 to 39—from borderline passing down to hopeless. (loc 2759)

• • •

There seem to be only two clearly demonstrated benefits of high self-esteem, according to the review panel. First, it increases initiative, probably because it lends confidence. People with high self-esteem are more willing to act on their beliefs, to stand up for what they believe in, to approach others, to risk new undertakings. (This unfortunately includes being extra willing to do stupid or destructive things, even when everyone else advises against them.) Second, it feels good. High self-esteem seems to operate like a bank of positive emotions, which furnish a general sense of well-being and can be useful when you need an extra dose of confidence to cope with misfortune, (loc 2782)

• • •

Narcissists are legends in their own mind and addicted to their grandiose images. They have a deep craving to be admired by other people (but don’t feel a special need to be liked—it’s adulation they require). They expect to be treated as special beings and will turn nasty when criticized. They tend to make very good first impressions but don’t wear well. When the psychologist Delroy Paulhus asked people in groups to rate one another, the narcissists seemed to be everyone’s favorite person, but only during the first few meetings. After a few months, they usually slipped to the bottom of the rankings. (loc 2790)

• • •

This broad rise in narcissism is the problem child of the self-esteem movement, and it is not likely to change anytime soon, because the movement persists despite the evidence that it’s not making children become more successful, honest, or otherwise better citizens. (loc 2801)

• • •

There’s one notable exception to the trend toward narcissism observed in psychological studies of young Americans. It doesn’t appear among young Asian-Americans, probably because their parents have been influenced less by the self-esteem movement than by a cultural tradition of instilling discipline. […]

After carefully reviewing IQ studies, Flynn concludes that the scores of Chinese-American and Japanese-American people are very similar to whites of European descent. If anything, the Asian-Americans’ IQ is slightly lower, on average, although they do show up more at both the upper and lower extremes. The big difference is that they make better use of their intelligence. (loc 2822)

• • •

there are three basic facets of punishment: severity, speed, and consistency. Many people associate strict discipline with severe penalties, but that’s actually the least important facet. Researchers have found that severity seems to matter remarkably little and can even be counterproductive: Instead of encouraging virtue, harsh punishments teach the child that life is cruel and that aggression is appropriate. (loc 2892)

• • •

children react well when reprimands are delivered briefly, calmly, and consistently (loc 2904)

• • •

Besides resenting the unfairness, you learn that the most important thing is not how you behave but whether or not you get caught, and whether your parents are in the mood to punish. You might learn, for instance, that table manners can be dispensed with at restaurants, because the grown-ups are too embarrassed to discipline you in public. (loc 2910)

• • •

Research has shown that children who open bank accounts are more likely than others to grow up to be savers. So are children who grow up discussing money with their parents. (loc 2964)

• • •
Dieting

The researchers gave it a formal scientific term, counterregulatory eating, but in their lab and among colleagues it was known simply as the what-the-hell effect. Dieters have a fixed target in mind for their maximum daily calories, and when they exceed it for some unexpected reason, such as being given a pair of large milkshakes in an experiment, they regard their diet as blown for the day. (loc 3207)

• • •

Humans are born with an innate gift for eating just the right amount. When an infant’s body needs food, it sends a signal through hunger pangs. When the body has had enough food, the infant doesn’t want to eat any more. Unfortunately, children start to lose this ability by the time they enter school, and it continues to decline later in life (loc 3223)

• • •

The researchers found that there was no connection between the women’s moods and their eating: The ones who were sadder after the movie didn’t eat extra ice cream to drown their sorrows. What mattered was not their mood but rather their will. The dieters who had suppressed emotions during the movie had a much harder time suppressing their appetite. (loc 3255)

• • •

Sweet food becomes especially hard to resist because, as we’ve already seen, self-control depletes the glucose in the bloodstream. If you’ve ever been on a diet and found yourself unable to shake those intrusive cravings for chocolate or ice cream, this is more than a matter of repressed desires coming back to haunt you. There is a sound physiological basis. (loc 3282)

• • •

The result suggests that telling yourself I can have this later operates in the mind a bit like having it now. It satisfies the craving to some degree—and can be even more effective at suppressing the appetite than actually eating the treat.

[…]

It takes willpower to turn down dessert, but apparently it’s less stressful on the mind to say Later rather than Never. In the long run, you end up wanting less and also consuming less. (loc 3436)

• • •
Misc

The shift in people’s characters was noticed by a psychoanalyst named Allen Wheelis, who in the late 1950s revealed what he considered a dirty little secret of his profession: Freudian therapies no longer worked the way they were supposed to. In his landmark book, The Quest for Identity, Wheelis described a change in character structure since Freud’s day. The Victorian middle-class citizens who formed the bulk of Freud’s patients had intensely strong wills, making it difficult for therapists to break through their ironclad defenses and their sense of what was right and wrong. Freud’s therapies had concentrated on ways to break through and let them see why they were neurotic and miserable, because once those people achieved insight, they could change rather easily. (loc 159)

• • •

Experts surmise that the smartest nonhuman primates can mentally project perhaps twenty minutes into the future—long enough to let the alpha male eat, but not long enough for much planning beyond dinner. (loc 275)

• • •

the classic Stroop task (named after psychologist James Stroop), requiring them to say what color some letters are printed in. […]

the Stroop task became a tool for American intelligence officials during the cold war. A covert agent could claim not to speak Russian, but he’d take longer to answer correctly when looking at Russian words for colors. (loc 462)

• • •

Mardi Gras means Fat Tuesday, the day before Ash Wednesday, when people prepare for a season of fasting and self-sacrifice by shamelessly indulging their desires. (loc 622)

• • •

Men who saw photos of hot women shifted toward getting an immediate reward instead of waiting for a larger payoff in the future. Apparently, the sight of an attractive woman makes men want cash right away. They focus on the present rather than the future. This effect is probably deeply rooted in the psyche and in the evolutionary past. […]

the sight of an attractive woman (but not an unattractive woman) activates the male brain’s nucleus accumbens, which is connected to the part of the brain activated by rewards like cash and sweet-tasting foods. In the past, there might well have been some evolutionary advantage in going for a quick display of resources upon seeing an attractive female; (loc 1564)

• • •

Contrary to popular stereotype, alcohol doesn’t increase your impulse to do stupid or destructive things; instead, it simply removes restraints. It lessens self-control in two ways: by lowering blood glucose and by reducing self-awareness. Therefore, it mainly affects behaviors marked by inner conflict, as when part of you wants to do something and part of you does not, (loc 2440)

• • •

Before heading down that river, Stanley wrote to his fiancée, telling her that he weighed just 118 pounds, having lost 60 pounds since seeing her. His many ailments included another bout of malaria, which had him shivering on a day when the temperature in the sun hit 138 degrees Fahrenheit. He expected worse hardships ahead, but he didn’t focus on them in the last letter he would be able to dispatch until reaching the other side of Africa. “My love towards you is unchanged, you are my dream, my stay, my hope, and my beacon,” he wrote to her. “I shall cherish you in this light until I meet you, or death meets me.” Stanley clung to that hope for another thirty-five hundred miles, taking the Lady Alice down the Congo River, surviving attacks from cannibals chanting a war cry of “Niama! Niama!”—Meat! Meat! Only half of his companions completed the journey to the Atlantic coast, which took nearly three years and claimed the life of every European except Stanley. (loc 2323)

• • •

Stanley ended up with a reputation as the harshest and most violent explorer of his age, when in fact he was unusually humane toward Africans, even by comparison with the gentle Livingstone, as Jeal demonstrates. (loc 2359)

• • •

This poor body of mine has suffered terribly . . . it has been degraded, pained, wearied & sickened, and has well nigh sunk under the task imposed on it; but this was but a small portion of myself. For my real self lay darkly encased, & was ever too haughty & soaring for such miserable environments as the body that encumbered it daily. (loc 2403)

• • •

entry.title: Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett
entry.summary: Nothing happens – twice. A canvas onto which we project meaning.
entry.content:
“No man ever steps through the same river twice” (Heraclitus). Unless you don’t know there’s a river! Waiting for Godot is a play where nothing happens – twice – but only on the second iteration do you realise that you are surrounded by whirling currents.

One year ago, almost to the day, I read Invisible Cities by Calvino, which to me was “deconstruction that eschews deconstructionism”. Waiting for Godot has a similar feel, but there is no construction to be deconstructed. Instead, it is a rapidfire, subtle, staccato blend of comic absurdity with bleak existential rumination, bridging Carroll and Camus.

A younger version of me would have been frustrated and tantalised by the lack of clear meaning. In fact, the only "low-hanging fruit" is the importance of companionship – amidst all the frustration, confusion, and pain, there is a heartening warmth in the relationship between Vladimir and Estragon. I would have doubtless constructed some theory to understand the play – perhaps treating Godot as an allegory for God, or seeing Pozzo and Lucky as representing master-slave dialectics.

But the sheer number of possible interpretations hints at something more abstract. Waiting for Godot is not a puzzle to be solved, but a canvas onto which meaning is projected. Ironically, this offers one possible solution to the very problem the play explores – how we find meaning in an uncaring universe. The play itself becomes both the canvas and the brush. Sisyphus is made happy by projecting meaning onto his toil, and imagining himself happy.

entry.title: Dynamic Hedging by Nassim Nicholas Taleb
entry.summary: Rules-of-thumb to survive as an options dealer
entry.content:
Dynamic Hedging is a book about defense, not offense. Here’s the scenario: you’ve just been handed a massive steaming pile of derivatives, and your task is simple – survive!

This is precisely the position of market makers. Their role is to sell options to buyers, buy options from whoever wants to sell them, and try to clip some edge without blowing up. This is a tough seat. Even with simple linear instruments like equities, counterparties typically trade with you when they have a view, so adverse selection is a constant worry. As an options market maker, you must also contend with the inherent complexities and nonlinearities of the instruments.

Taleb, as far as we know, was rather good at this, and Dynamic Hedging distills the wisdom that he gained from his time in the trenches. This wisdom primarily comprises practical rules-of-thumb and empirical techniques focused on risk management – a guide to navigating the countless ways you can lose money trading options.

Yes, in places it feels dated, which is understandable for a book written in 1997. Modern textbooks offer more precise and rigorous explanations of volatility smiles and term structure, largely because we culturally have a much better understanding of how to use the Black-Scholes-Merton model – as a change of variables rather than a prescriptive valuation formula.

But the book’s intuitive approach allows you to survive even in the absence of sophisticated theory. This becomes particularly crucial when dealing with complex exotics, where “modern” analytic methods may struggle due to both limitations of the theoretical machinery, and a lack of knowledge from the trader. In this light, while the book may be old-fashioned, it remains highly relevant, serving as a comprehensive guide to avoiding financial catastrophe.

entry.title: Tokyo Express by Seichō Matsumoto
entry.summary: Charming, rapidfire detective novel set on the railways of postwar Japan
entry.content:
Tokyo Express is a charming detective novel set in the energetic, almost optimistic bustle of postwar Japan. But it’s hard to stay too optimistic in the face of a tragic double suicide – especially when one of the victims happens to be a key figure in a political conspiracy… I’ll say no more.

The writing is engaging without being flowery, with Matsumoto expertly managing the tempo as we navigate a complex plot. The presto of zipping through different parts of Japan by rail contrasts pleasantly with the andante of meandering through a quiet seaside town, or sitting in a warm Tokyo cafe, as the detective contemplates the case. Unfortunately, the novel is let down by its exposition: the entire denouement unfolds, rather anticlimactically, through a letter from the detective to a colleague. There’s no dramatic revelation where the murderer is caught red-handed, nor a triumphant, witty soliloquy from a Poirot or Holmes. On this basis, If I were a rigorous literary critic, I would have to give Tokyo Express three stars.

Thankfully, one of the joys of being an amateur book reviewer is freedom from such constraints. What can I say, the book just has a certain charm. It transported me to the heart of the Tokyo Railway station in Chiyoda (which I was lucky enough to visit on a family holiday in November 2017), surrounded by busy salarymen rushing for their commuter trains as sleek Shinkansen glide in and out. If you’ve ever found yourself mesmerised by train schedules, or delighted in cutting things very fine in order to squeeze the most out of your travel, Tokyo Express is irresistible.

Highlights

He recognized a few regulars. The place hadn't changed in the slightest while he was away. For the waitress and customers alike, life at the cafe had been carrying on as usual. On the other side of the window; the streets of Ginza seemed unchanged, too. It was as though, for the five or six days he'd been away, he alone had beer thrust from this world. Nobody here knew what Mihara had been up to during the intervening days - and, despite the unusual things he had seen, nobody showed even a passing interest in him. Of course, this was only natural, and yet it left him feeling strangely lonely (p. 53)

I love this kind of “saudade” that often appears in Japanese novels. Loneliness can find you even in a busy place

…

entry.title: What is This Thing Called Knowledge? by Duncan Pritchard
entry.summary: If only it were as easy as “justified true belief”
entry.content:
What is This Thing Called Knowledge? is Duncan Pritchard’s courageous attempt at introducing all of epistemology – the theory of knowledge – in a relatively brief text. It centres around the titular question: what on Earth is knowledge?

The classical tripartite account – that knowledge is justified true belief – is an acceptable starting point, but it quickly runs into problems. Consider Agrippa’s trilemma regarding the justification of knowledge: either our knowledge is unjustified, circularly justified, or justified by an infinite chain. With some work, we find that these are somewhat tenable, so perhaps the classical account is onto something. But then, in 1963, the young philosopher Edmund Gettier published a devastating three-page article that all but killed the classical understanding and sparked a renaissance in epistemology. Amusingly, Gettier thereafter showed little interest in epistemology, and never again published in the field.

Gettier cases are situations in which, by coincidence, your reasoning leads to a belief that happens to be true. For example, you see the time on your watch is 9am, and it indeed happens to be 9am, but your watch was actually broken. Here, you have a justified true belief of the time that is clearly not knowledge. A quick fix might be to redefine knowledge to be justified true belief gained reliably , which addresses the broken watch example, but this is still vulnerable to Gettier-style attacks. There’s the amusing case of a farmer seeing a sheep in the field, but instead of a sheep, it is someone wearing a sheep costume, behind whom there is a real sheep. The farmer has justified true belief that there is a sheep in the field, formed reliably, but it’s not clear that we can call this knowledge either.

One of the modern resolutions is virtue epistemology, which despite its apparent fluffiness, I eventually found quite compelling. Virtue epistemology shifts the focus to the agents forming the beliefs. For a true belief to become knowledge, the belief must be true due to intellectual virtues of the agent, rather than just luck. Sosa summarises knowledge thus: the belief must be true (accurate), formed competently through intellectual virtues (adroit), and true because of the agent’s competence (apt). Building from this slightly more solid footing, Pritchard explores several “areas of knowledge”, for example, scientific and religious knowledge.

One key area not addressed by Pritchard is probabilistic knowledge. Perhaps I am biased by my day job as a trader, but the fact that the world is full of aleatory uncertainty (let alone the epistemic variety) is a fairly pertinent issue. But it’s not clear how to proceed – even the most basic concept of “true belief” is not trivially applied to probabilistic statements. It strikes me that virtue epistemology is one approach: by making use of cognitive faculties (like being a good Bayesian updater), we can strive to maximise the correlation between our beliefs and reality.

I can’t finish this review without mentioning Frank Ramsey, that great polymath who died at 26 and remains salient in my mind after reading Cheryl Misak’s biography (Frank Ramsey: a Sheer Excess of Powers) earlier this year. Ramsey, whose name unfortunately does not once feature in Pritchard’s book, was concerned with the deep ideas underlying epistemology – the nature of justification, truth, and belief – rather than taking those as a given and defining knowledge therewith. Had he not died at 26, I like to think that he might have completed the manuscript On Truth, and eventually linked it with his distinct pragmatic philosophy and deep knowledge of the philosophy of probability to produce a practical Bayesian epistemology. With Ramsey in mind, my answer to the question what is this thing called knowledge: knowledge is that which helps us make better decisions that guide us on the road to eudaimonia.

Key ideas

  • What is Knowledge: start with Justified True Belief.
    • Epistemology is concerned with propositional knowledge rather than ability knowledge (e.g. knowing how to swim)
    • Most epistemologists agree that a necessary condition is true belief
    • Assume that truth is objective: belief in something does not make it true
  • Rationality: related to epistemology but not the same
    • Epistemic rationality is aimed at forming true beliefs, as opposed to a more general rationality which sometimes suggests that you should delude yourself if it increases utility.
    • Deontic epistemic rationality: someone is rational if they are following their own epistemic norms (decision processes) well. Non-deontic epistemic rationality also requires that these epistemic norms be correct.
    • Demotic epistemic rationality is a form of Epistemic internalism. Epistemic internalists hold that knowledge is due to internal processes. Epistemic externalists: whether or not you have knowledge depends on external factors, like whether you were raised with the correct epistemic norms.
  • Classical ideas in epistemology:
    • The problem of the criterion: you can only identify knowledge if you have criteria; you can only have criteria if you can identify instances of knowledge.
    • Agrippa’s trilemma: either our beliefs are ultimately unjustified, they are justified by an infinite chain, or they are circular. Three main resolutions:
      • Infinitism: infinite chain can justify belief
      • Coherentism (Quine): circular justification is valid
      • Classical foundationalism (Descartes): knowledge is a chain of justifications that terminates on self-justifying foundational beliefs.
  • Modern accounts of epistemology:
    • The classical/tripartite account of knowledge – justified true belief – suffers from Gettier cases (1963), where you have a justified true belief due to luck (seeing a broken clock that is coincidentally showing the right time). No easy solution.
    • Reliabilism: knowledge is justified true belief that has been gained reliably. Still suffers from Gettier cases, for example the dog in the sheep costume, behind which there is a sheep.
    • Virtue epistemology: knowledge is true belief gained by one’s epistemic virtues or reliable cognitive faculties. This is an epistemic internalist belief; would not consider chicken-sexers to have knowledge (they can reliably identify chickenpox sex but have false ideas about how they do it).
    • Sosa’s virtue epistemology has three criteria:
      1. Accuracy: The belief is true.
      2. Adroitness: The belief is formed competently through intellectual virtues.
      3. Aptness: The belief is true because of the agent’s competence.

Inference, induction, and the philosophy of science

  • If a valid argument has true premises, it is also a sound argument.
  • Abduction: generate the best explanation of a single phenomenon (what Sherlock does). Induction is a generalisation of Abduction.
  • Popper uses falsificationism to escape the problem of induction. Start by making a hypothesis: all swans are white, then if you find a black swan you can deductively know that not all swans are white.
  • Reichenbach gives the pragmatic argument that without induction, we won’t have many true beliefs.
  • Kuhn’s scientific revolutions:
    • Science proceeds in revolutionary paradigm shifts
    • Early Kuhn believed that the new paradigm is not just a new set of concepts, but a completely different truth-seeking process, with different standards for relevant evidence.
    • In this framing, scientific knowledge is not “accumulating” – each new paradigm completely reinterprets (or discards) the old.
    • Kuhn moderated on this later in life.

Religious and moral knowledge

  • Classical attempts at justifying religion rationally:
    • Ontological argument: God is definitionally the greatest thing to exist. If God didn’t exist, then one could conceive of a greater being, with the same attributes as God but which existed. This leads to a contradiction, so God must exist. Kant’s critique: it treats existence as an attribute, but really existence is about whether a list of attributes corresponds to the real world.
    • Cosmological principle: something must have created the universe
    • Intelligent design: only a powerful intelligent being can account for the complexity of the world.
  • Evidentialist challenge to religious knowledge: religious beliefs lack supporting independent evidence (evidence that would be considered reliable even by someone without religious belief).
  • Fideism: religion is outside of the scope of epistemic requirements
  • Reformed epistemology (Alvin Plantinga):
    • For other types of knowledge (e.g. that gained by perception), we don’t require independent evidence. Hence we should maybe allow for a religious believer’s sensus divinatus.
    • Challenges: unlike perception, not everyone has this sensus divinatus . Also, reformed epistemology allows for Flying Spaghetti Monster.
  • Moral expressionism: moral statements are no facts, but they express feelings about what one should and shouldn’t do.
  • Classical foundationalism: we have a priori knowledge of basic moral principles, which we then combine with situational facts to form moral knowledge.

Social knowledge

  • Key epistemological questions in various fields:
    • Education: goal of education is the development of epistemological virtues.
    • Legal: higher standard of evidence required because of the social cost of being wrong.
    • Politics: fake news, like bad science, is not just news (science) done poorly. It is epistemically different as it is designed to mislead. Defeater: something that can prevent you from having knowledge, by questioning your reasoning, or providing alternate reasons why your belief is false.
  • Ignorance: just because we do not know something (e.g. in Gettier cases) does not make us ignorant. We can treat ignorance as a lack of knowledge in the Virtue Epistemology sense.
  • Epistemic injustice: social dynamics that inhibit virtue epistemology
    • Hermeneutical injustice: existing social structures prevent someone from identifying their current situation. E.g. “sexual harassment” as a concept was only developed in the 1970s
    • Testimonial injustice: “the credibility of someone’s testimony is downgraded as a result of prejudice”

Sceptisicism, truth and objectivity

  • Anti-realism: truth is just our best opinion and therefore can’t be different.
  • Problem of other minds: we are unable to observe the mind of another, so how do we know there are other minds? But we can argue from analogy: I know my behaviour is correlated to my mental state, so I can inductively reason about the mental states of others.
  • Radical scepticism is a style of challenging any theory of knowledge.
    • A sceptical hypothesis: what if you were in the Matrix being deceived?
    • Because we are unable to know that the sceptical hypothesis is false, how can we know anything?
  • Approaches:
    • Sensitivity: we claim that knowledge is concerned with beliefs that are sensitive to the truth (i.e. if the thing weren’t true, the agent wouldn’t have believed it). Sceptical hypotheses are insensitive, and thus outside of the scope
    • Safety principle: knowledge is about having “safe” true beliefs – if an agent forms that belief in similar circumstances, it will almost always be true.
    • Contextualism: knowledge is about contextual truth.

Highlights

Perception and idealism

The view which denies that there is an external world in this sense – that is, which denies that there is a world that is independent of our experience of it – is known as idealism (loc 1706)

• • •

Kant agrees with the simple idealist that what we are immediately aware of in sensory experience is not the world itself. Nevertheless, unlike the idealist, he argues that we are required to suppose that there is an external world that gives rise to this sensory experience since, without this supposition, we would not be able to make any sense of such experience. (loc 1736)

• • •

We began by noting a distinction between a priori knowledge and empirical knowledge. The former is knowledge that you have gained without having to investigate the world (i.e. armchair knowledge), while the latter is gained, at least in part, via a worldly investigation. An important kind of a priori knowledge is gained by introspection, which is where we ‘look inwardly’ and examine our own psychological states rather than ‘look outwardly’ and investigate the world. As we saw, however, not all introspective knowledge is a priori knowledge. (loc 2237)

• • •

any legitimate form of abductive inference will be an abbreviated version of an inductive inference. (loc 2249)

• • •
Induction and the philosophy of science

Good tests kill flawed theories; we remain alive to guess again. Popper (attributed) (loc 2354)

• • •

judgement passed down by one Judge William Overton in 1982, in a famous ruling known as McLean versus the Arkansas Board of Education. The background to the case was that it had been decreed that creationism should be taught in publicly funded schools in Arkansas alongside evolutionary theory as an alternative scientific account of our origins.

The court case was brought by those unhappy with this development, who argued that creationism is not a scientific proposal but merely the expression of a certain religious view, and hence had no place being taught in a US publicly funded school (since the US constitution forbids the advocacy of religion in publicly funded schools). After hearing the testimony of various parties, including the testimony of several influential philosophers of science, Judge Overton was called upon to give a ruling in this case. (loc 2565)

• • •

is bad science thereby pseudo-science? This is a deep point, in that while there is clearly a difference to be drawn between bad science and pseudo-science, the distinction is far from sharp. Indeed, once we acknowledge that genuine science can be done badly, then this raises the question of why we should exclude creationism from the canon of genuine science at all. Why not instead regard it merely as genuine science done in a sub-optimal way (i.e. as bad science, rather than pseudo-science)? (loc 2641)

• • •

Kuhn argues for the incommensurability of the new revolutionary scientific theory and the old scientific theory it is replacing. That is, the former is not an adaption of the latter as the ‘incremental’ view of scientific progress suggests, but rather a radical new way of scientific theorising which has nothing that is clearly in common with the old view. As a result, it is difficult, if not impossible, to compare the two scientific paradigms side by side, since they each constitute radically different ways of scientific theorising, not only in terms of how they respond to the scientific evidence but also in terms of what they take the relevant scientific evidence to be in the first place. (loc 2718)

• • •

it calls into question the very idea of scientific progress as the accumulation of scientific knowledge. Notice that if scientific revolutions incorporate such radical theoretical change, then the new scientific knowledge that accrues after the scientific revolution can hardly be thought to be incorporating the body of scientific knowledge constituted by the old scientific theory. (loc 2723)

• • •

in the Kuhnian picture, the old scientific paradigm may well be very adept at accommodating the empirical evidence, and relative to this paradigm there may well be no definitive empirical counter-evidence which is fatal to the view. Of course, the new scientific paradigm may have a conception of the scientific evidence on which the old scientific paradigm is refuted, but a paradigm-relative falsification of a theory is quite different from the kind of falsification that Judge Overton had in mind, (loc 2734)

• • •

in later life, Kuhn himself seemed to significantly moderate his position. (loc 2746)

• • •
Religious and moral knowledge

[Reformed epistemology]

imagine that one were confronted by someone sceptical about the possibility of perceptual knowledge. Could one offer adequate evidence in support of one’s perceptual beliefs that is independent in this way (i.e. which even the sceptic about perceptual knowledge would grant as being good evidence)? Clearly, the natural evidence that one might offer in this regard (i.e. the evidence of one’s senses) is disallowed, since this is evidence that is gained via perception itself, the putative source of knowledge which is being called into question.

[…]

Reformed epistemologists claim that if we can make sense of how our innate sensory faculties can, in the right conditions, lead us to rationally held perceptual belief and perceptual knowledge, then we ought to be able to make sense of how a corresponding story can be told about religious belief, such that the believer’s innate religious faculty – her sensus divinitatis – can in the right conditions lead her to rationally held religious belief and (if the beliefs so formed are true) religious knowledge. (loc 3032)

• • •

If one holds that there are no moral facts, then one is endorsing moral expressivism. Moral expressivism holds that moral statements do not express facts but rather perform a very different role instead (e.g. expressing one’s support for a certain action or one’s desire to stop certain actions from taking place). (loc 3426)

• • •
Social knowledge: disagreements and ignorance

disagreements can prevent us from having knowledge that we might have otherwise possessed. After all, not everyone’s opinion is on a par, and so insofar as we do take disagreements seriously, then we might be in danger of losing knowledge (loc 3508)

• • •

Another way that disagreement can destroy genuine knowledge is by being a defeater for that knowledge. A defeater is a consideration that prevents you from having knowledge either by indicating that the reasons for your belief don’t sufficiently support the truth of that belief or else by providing you with independent reasons for thinking that the belief is false. (loc 3514)

• • •

In particular, unless you are able to acquire further reasons that enable you to discount this defeater, such as grounds to think that the people who think that Riga isn’t the capital of Latvia are making some kind of mistake, then this defeater undermines your knowledge, even though the defeater in question isn’t true. Notice too that the defeater will undermine your knowledge even if you continue to believe that Riga is the capital of Latvia. (loc 3534)

• • •

normative account of ignorance, in that it holds that ignorance involves, in addition to a lack of an epistemic standing, a further claim about how the subject has failed to satisfy a relevant norm. In particular, due to an intellectual failing on her part, she has failed know what she ought to have known, (loc 3924)

• • •

Fricker argues that epistemic injustice comes in two forms: hermeneutical injustice and testimonial injustice. Hermeneutical injustice is concerned with how the existing social structures in place can prevent someone from being able to properly identify their situation, thereby epistemically disadvantaging them. (loc 3973)

• • •
Misc

Touching the Void is a famous documentary made in 2003. It is a dramatic retelling of a real-life incident involving two mountain climbers who face disaster after one of them has an accident on the mountain Siula Grande in the Peruvian Andes. One of the most spectacular scenes in the film concerns the moment when the main protagonist has to make a choice between certain death and the unknown. He has fallen deep into the heart of a glacier and is now hanging there in the darkness unable, due to his injuries, to climb out. The choice he is faced with is either to hang there in the darkness until he eventually passes out and dies, or else cut the rope and let himself fall deeper into the darkness of the glacier below him. (loc 2421)

• • •
Book recommendations

Blackburn, Simon (2005) Truth: A Guide for the Perplexed (Harmondsworth: Allen Lane). A very readable introduction to the issues as regards the philosophy of truth. This is a good place to start if you want to learn more about this topic. (loc 283)

…

Dowden, Bradley & Shwartz, Norman (2006) ‘Truth’, Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, www.iep.utm.edu/t/truth.htm. A neat and comprehensive overview of the philosophical discussions regarding truth. Note that it can be a little demanding for the beginner in some places. (loc 301)

…

Annas, Julia (2003) Plato: A Very Short Introduction (Oxford: Oxford University Press). This is a succinct and very readable introduction to Plato’s philosophy (loc 491)

…

entry.title: Oceanic by Greg Egan
entry.summary: Wildly creative hard-scifi with a focus on AI and space exploration
entry.content:
Greg Egan is one of those authors who is little known outside his genre (hard sci-fi) and perhaps inscrutable to lay readers, but unforgettable for true fans. Oceanic is a compelling collection that fully justifies Egan’s reputation as the “hardest” hard sci-fi author. Rather than simply stating that “an interstellar probe was sent”, Egan dives into the plausible-yet-fictional physics behind the probe, often in excessive detail.

In another Egan anthology, Axiomatic, the core themes are mind-body dualism and simulated consciousness. Oceanic relegates these concepts to the background – as if digital copies of consciousness are already commonplace – allowing Egan to focus more thematically on AI safety and space travel. It’s a well-constructed collection with a cohesive “cinematic universe,” though each story stands on its own. For example, the synthetic human Helen from Singleton reappears in Oracle , explaining how humanity ends up in synthetic bodies. Induction chronicles Earth’s galactic expansion through “spores” that land in new solar systems and use nanomachines to build infrastructure, ready to receive beamed consciousnesses and load them into new bodies. The story’s title hints at Egan’s suggestion that once this is achieved for one planet, it will soon spread across the galaxy by induction. This groundwork builds toward Riding the Crocodile , Glory , and Hot Rock , which feature a post-scarcity galactic society called the Amalgam. Here, inhabitants can choose to live as digital consciousnesses or inhabit synthetic bodies, freely exploring worlds as they please.

Having said that, the best story in the collection is the standalone Dark Integers . This is Egan at his most creative. Mathematics itself obeys Einstein locality, allowing different parts of the universe to have different mathematical truth. Aliens are involved. It’s wacky, mind-bending, and Hofstadter-coded, and pushes the boundaries of conceptual sci-fi. The same can be said of Egan more generally. But it’s not for the faint of heart!

Synopses

  • Lost Continent : intertemporal religious war sparks intertemporal immigration crisis; a commentary on Australia’s migration policies.
  • Dark Integers : Egan at his most creative. Mathematics itself obeys Einstein locality, so different parts of the universe can have different mathematical truth. Alien contact is made by discovering a region of the universe with different mathematical axioms.
  • Crystal Nights: a billionaire tries to evolve a new species on a supercomputer. His creation is not as grateful as he expected: they figure out real-world physics and use it to escape.
  • Steve Fever : a dying scientist creates an AGI and asks it to revive him. Steve-flavoured paperclip maximisation ensues.
  • Induction : a short story about interplanetary colonisation using “orchid seeds” that acquire resources on the new planet, to which you can beam your consciousness.
  • Singleton : a scientist, unable to accept the many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics, invents a way of creating a singleton consciousness who never branches.
  • Oracle : a fanciful alternate history in which a traveller from another parallel universe (the synthetic human Helen from Singleton ) meets a thinly-veiled Alan Turing, and ushers in rapid technological innovation.
  • Border Guards : a mere 10 millennia after humans become immortal and interplanetary, a former mortal struggles to integrate.
  • Riding the Crocodile : in a galactic society called the Amalgalm, all the various species live on a common network and share resources, apart from the enigmatic “Aloof ones” living in the central bulge of the galaxy. All attempts to send probes are gently rebuffed. Leila and Jasim, ready for death after ten thousand years of marriage, decide that their final project will be to make contact.
  • Glory : species are either seekers (seeking new knowledge) or spreaders (wanting to indoctrinate others). In the Amalgalm, a pair of seekers tries to discover lost mathematics, but spreaders get in the way.
  • Hot Rock : an orphan planet full of intelligent lizards, that is “hot” because the ground is some kind of computronium. Good if you like particle physics.
  • Oceanic : a strange story about amphibious humans and religion.

Highlights

Lost Continent

Whether the Scholars were from the past or the future was unclear, but they certainly had weapons and vehicles from the future. (loc 65)

• • •

The heart of the storm was dark, thick with sand, knotted with wind. Ali’s chest tightened. This was it: the pol-e-waqt, the bridge between times. Everyone in his village had heard of such things, but nobody could agree what they were: the work of men, the work of djinn, the work of God. Whatever their origin, some men had learned their secrets. (loc 124)

• • •

There is no pol-e-waqt that connects past and future in the same world. Once you cross the bridge, everything changes, including the past.” (loc 288)

• • •
Dark Integers

The inhabitants of the far side were as peaceable as anyone might reasonably wish their neighbors to be, but if their mathematical infrastructure came under threat they faced the real prospect of annihilation. They had defended themselves from such a threat once before, but because they had been able to trace it to its source and understand its nature, they had shown great forbearance. They had not struck their assailants dead, or wiped out Shanghai, or pulled the ground out from under our universe. (loc 633)

• • •

The ghost world was far from hostile, but the treaty was the most important in human history, because either side had the power to annihilate the other so thoroughly that it would make a nuclear holocaust seem like a pin-prick. (loc 716)

• • •

“What you and Dr. Tierney suggested was that random processes in the early universe might have included proofs of mutually contradictory theorems about the integers, the idea being that no computation to expose the inconsistency had yet had time to occur. Is that a fair summary?” (loc 764)

• • •

Yuen had proclaimed that the flow of mathematical information did obey Einstein locality; there was no universal book of truths, just records of the past sloshing around at lightspeed or less, intermingling and competing. (loc 776)

• • •

arithmetic wasn’t merely inconsistent, it was dynamic. You could take its contradictions and slide them around like bumps in a carpet. (loc 832)

• • •

A “proof” concerning the integers was just a class of physical processes, and the result of that proof was neither read from, nor written to, any universal book of truths. Rather, the agreement between proofs was simply a strong, but imperfect, correlation between the different processes that counted as proofs of the same thing. Those correlations arose from the way that the primordial states of Planck-scale physics were carved up – imperfectly – into subsystems that appeared to be distinct objects. The truths of mathematics appeared to be enduring and universal because they persisted with great efficiency within the states of matter and space-time. (loc 1077)

• • •

The closer the attack front came to simple arithmetic, the more resistance it would face from natural processes voting at the border for near-side results. Our enemy had their supercomputers; we had every every atom of the Earth, following its billion-year-old version of the truth. (loc 1334)

• • •
Crystal Nights

“Evolution,” she said, “is about failure and death. Do you have any idea how many sentient creatures lived and died along the way to Homo sapiens? How much suffering was involved?” “Part of your job would be to minimize the suffering.” (loc 1528)

• • •

“I’m grateful to exist,” she agreed, “but in the human case the suffering wasn’t deliberately inflicted by anyone, and nor was there any alternative way we could have come into existence. If there really had been a just creator, I don’t doubt that he would have followed Genesis literally; he sure as hell would not have used evolution.” “Just, and omnipotent,” Daniel suggested. “Sadly, that second trait’s even rarer than the first.” (loc 1535)

• • •

“You know what they say the modern version of Pascal’s Wager is? Sucking up to as many Transhumanists as possible, just in case one of them turns into God. Perhaps your motto should be ‘Treat every chatterbot kindly, it might turn out to be the deity’s uncle.’” (loc 1555)

• • •

Daniel let them imagine that they were working toward restoring fertility; after all, that was perfectly true, even if their goal was a few conceptual revolutions further away than they realized. Humans had had their naïve notions of a Philosopher’s Stone dashed, but they’d still achieved nuclear transmutation in the end. (loc 1760)

• • •

“We need the Phites themselves to act as translators,” he told Lucien. “We need to contrive a situation where there’s a large enough pool who choose not to be boosted that the old language continues to be used.” “So we need maybe twenty-five per cent refusing the boost?” Lucien suggested. “And we need the boosted Phites to want to keep them informed of what’s happening, in terms that we can all understand.” (loc 1800)

• • •

seems to me that you were ill-prepared for the task you set yourself. If you’d waited for the machine you really needed, our lives would not have been so hard. And if such a machine could not be built in your lifetime, what was to stop your grandchildren from taking on that task?” “I had no choice,” Daniel insisted. “I couldn’t leave your creation to my descendants. There is a war coming between my people. I needed your help. I needed strong allies.” (loc 1861)

• • •

It seemed the Phites had discovered the Higgs field, and engineered a burst of something akin to cosmic inflation. What they’d done wasn’t as simple as merely inflating a tiny patch of vacuum into a new universe, though. Not only had they managed to create a “cool Big Bang”, they had pulled a large chunk of ordinary matter into the pocket universe they’d made, after which the wormhole leading to it had shrunk to subatomic size and fallen through the Earth. (loc 1964)

• • •
Steve Fever

He banged his head against the table. “Make it stop! Get them out of me!” His mother put an arm around his shoulders. “You know we can’t wave a magic wand and get rid of them. You’ve got the latest counterware. All we can do is send a sample to be analyzed, do our bit to speed the process along.” (loc 2077)

• • •

Steve Hasluck had been part of a team of scientists developing a new kind of medical nanomachine, refining the tiny surgical instruments so they could make decisions of their own, on the spot. Steve’s team had developed an efficient way of sharing computing power across a whole swarm, allowing them to run large, complex programs known as “expert systems” that codified decades of biological and clinical knowledge into pragmatic lists of rules. […] Then Steve found out that he had cancer, and that his particular kind wasn’t on anyone’s list of rules. […]

Steve decided that the swarms still had too narrow a view. He gave them a general-purpose knowledge acquisition engine and let them drink at will from the entire web. To guide their browsing and their self-refinement, he gave them two clear goals. The first was to do no harm to their hosts. The second was to find a way to save his life, and failing that, to bring him back from the dead. […]

Within months of their escape, it must have become clear to them that some hurdles could only be jumped with human assistance, because that was when they started borrowing people. Doing them no physical harm, but infesting them with the kinds of ideas and compulsions that turned the m into willing recruits. The panic, the bombings, the Crash had followed. Lincoln hadn’t witnessed the worst of it. He hadn’t seen conclaves of harmless sleepwalkers burned to death by mobs, or fields of grain napalmed by the government, lest they feed and shelter nests of rats. (loc 2168)

• • •

The Steveware controlled vast financial assets, some flat-out stolen from sleepwalkers, but much of it honestly acquired by trading the products of the rat factories: everything from high-grade pharmaceuticals to immaculately faked designer shoes. (loc 2195)

• • •

“They’ve studied the anatomy of ten million human brains, but I think they know that they still don’t fully understand consciousness. They bring in real people for the bit parts, so they can concentrate on the star. If you gave them a particular human brain, I’m sure they could faithfully copy it into software, but anything more complicated starts to get murky. How do they know their Steve is conscious, when they’re not conscious themselves? He never gave them a reverse Turing test, a checklist they could apply. All they have is the judgment of people like you.” (loc 2306)
