entry.title: Inferno by Dante Alighieri
entry.summary: Deeply considered schema of sin, though often allegorical for petty political feuds
entry.content:
Most people think that Dante’s Inferno is just a description of Hell and the punishments therein, through the eyes of a pious and judgmental Christian. This is technically correct, but it’s like saying that The Lord of the Rings is about some guys looking for a powerful ring. Such a reductive take completely misses the point.

Dante instead paints a very nuanced (and often surprising) picture of sin and its consequences. While he was a devout Christian (and I suppose it’s fair to call him a judgmental one at that), he is not one for blind faith. Dante’s whole conception of the Divine order is based on his central perspective that rationality is humanity’s jewel. This is not unlike Aquinas, who believed that reason was a path to Divine “truth” (interestingly, Aquinas predates Dante by a few decades). Accordingly, sins that abuse the power of rationality (especially sins of deceit) are treated far more severely. This is somewhat reflected in Dante’s surprising choice of Virgil, a pagan, as his guide. While it might be an oversimplification to say that Virgil represents rationality, Virgil is portrayed as an ever-wise 'spirit level' (ha ha).

An important piece of historical context is that Dante was exiled from Florence – at times, Inferno feels surprisingly political for what is ostensibly a book on theology. Dante spends several cantos describing the punishments given to various of his political enemies, and it honestly feels petty and vindictive.

By contrast, there are some cantos that are hugely ambitious and utterly fascinating – for example, when Dante judges classical characters such as Ulysses (Odysseus). I was surprised to find Ulysses in such a deep pocket of Hell, but it’s consistent with Dante’s view that the abuse of rationality/intellect (e.g the Trojan horse) is a despicable corruption of humanity’s greatest gift. That said, this might be explained by the fact that Ulysses was painted as a lot more deceitful and devious in the Aeneid (which Dante read), rather than cunning and intelligent as in the Iliad (which Dante did not read).

The final encounter with Lucifer, which is meant to be the climax of the book, is really anything but. This is part of Dante’s genius – in his well-reasoned perspective, sin is nothing but an absence of Divine love. Lucifer is portrayed as a stupid, ugly and mechanical being. His three heads make for a comic parody of the Holy Trinity.

Overall, Inferno is drier than one might expect and oftentimes quite hard to get through. I do think it’s worth reading, but one must be prepared for a stream of political and social references that will fly over one’s head. I wish I could have experienced the terza rima in the original Italian. I read a version with the Italian printed on every other page, and there really is some melodious magic to reading it out loud (I could only understand a fraction of it, thanks to IB spanish!)

Historical Context

  • Dante’s bitterness int he face of exile from Florence is one of his main motivators
  • At the time the Guelphs (supporting the Papacy) and the Ghibellines (supporting the Holy Roman Empire) were in constant conflict. Dante was a firm Ghibelline, and was definitely not a fan of Pope Boniface.
  • Dante feels that Florence has become too mercantile, he refers to the new unified currency as the ‘maladetto fiore’ (accursed flower).
  • Dante’s love for Beatrice, who died when she was 24.

Dante’s fundamentals

  • A charitable love, compared to the overpowering love discussed by some of his contemporaries like Cavalcanti.
  • In his view, having one emperor avoids cupidita (avarice/greed).
  • A believer in rationalism, but a rationalism that supports Christian faith. Development from the Aristotlean logic that Aquinas renewed a few years earlier.
  • To some extent, obsessed with the idea of Rome, thinking about it as the idealised Empire. This may be why he chose the pagan Virgil as his guide, rather than a Christian figure. He seems to remain wilfully ignorant of all of the bad aspects of the Roman empire.
  • Dante is an expert in nuance, in many aspects of life. In Inferno he carefully grades different sins. In his social life, he has made enemies of some people while holding their siblings in highest esteem.

La Commedia

  • Made the decision to write the Commedia in Italian, rather than Latin. He has discussed this in some of the other works. He wants it to be ‘nutritious’ for the people reading it – something which Latin is not suited for.
  • Some similarity between the Commedia’s terza rima and Aristotle’s syllogistic logic
  • Virgil is an unnatural choice of guide, but it is an emphasis that he wants Florence to return to the ethical and judicial standards of Rome. In some sense, he may be trying to anchor his work in the stage of political history. However, stylistically, Dante differs quite heavily from Virgil. Instead of the sombre narrative continuum that Virgil adopts in his epics, Dante writes in a more episodic manner, with much shorter cantos.
  • Dante is not just a spirit in Inferno, he is an actual body (in canto 12, he kicks a stone that leads to us seeing the Minotaur). The human body is very important to Dante, and he is not a cartesian dualist. Although rationality is fundamental, that rationality has to act through a physical medium (and experience the Earthly temptations!)
  • Dante, at the end of Inferno, is humble regarding his account of the Divine order. It is the impatience to name and understand that condemned Lucifer to fall: “through not waiting for the light, he fell unripe”.
  • Dante takes pleasure in asking ‘why’ – this culminates in Paradiso which is almost a ‘game’ of some sorts

Inferno

  • Often quite dry, because of excessive descriptions of Dante's contemporaries. However, he has a very fine moral sense and literary skill. Consigning Ulysses to a rather deep pocket of hell was a very interesting move.
  • Rationality above all
  • Dante has come very close to committing some of the sins he has discussed.
  • The anticlimax of Satan and the contrasts to the trinity

entry.title: Kafka on the Shore by Haruki Murakami
entry.summary: Magical realist exploration of fate – the iconic Murakami novel
entry.content:
Sputnik Sweetheart marked a turning point in my view of Murakami; it made me set aside my previous reservations and explore more of his work.

Kafka on the Shore retains Murakami’s signature “weirdness” but is also a genuinely engaging mystery, full of subtle layers for readers who pay close attention. It stands out as a strong example of magical realism, evoking the style of contemporary Márquez.

Fate is one of the novel’s key themes, which explains the prominent Oedipal imagery (and at times, more than just imagery). While this can make parts of the novel uncomfortable, it effectively conveys Kafka’s struggle with his father’s prophecy – a reminder that the fault lies not in our stars but in ourselves. I also appreciate how Murakami explores Time: not only is it central to the plot, but it’s also deeply embedded in the novel’s structure.

Some aspects of the novel still puzzle me, like the occasional shifts from third-person to second-person narration, but given its complexity, I’m inclined to trust that Murakami had a purpose. The fault is not in the novel but in myself.

Highlights

"Kafka, in everybody's life there's a point of no return. And in a very few cases, a point where you can't go forward anymore. And when we reach that point, all we can do is quietly accept the fact. That's how we survive."

...

People are drawn deeper into tragedy not by their defects but by their virtues.

...

In a place where time isn't important, neither is memory.

entry.title: Kokoro by Natsume Soseki
entry.summary: The struggle of the “thinking and feeling heart” in dealing with societal sea changes
entry.content:
Japanese is a very expressive language, containing many words without direct English translations. A famous example, most likely popularised by Tumblr, is komorebi (sunlight filtering through trees). “Kokoro” is another word that is hard to translate:

The novel, a classic in Japan, presents the relationship between a young man and Sensei. However, underlying the relatively simple plot is the strong symbolism of the fading Meiji era and the subsequent internationalisation of Japan (a recurring theme in much of 20th-century Japanese literature). While this shift was viewed positively by many, it left the older generation grappling with feelings of guilt, embodied in the “thinking and feeling heart” that Kokoro captures so well. But even without this deeper historical context, Kokoro stands as a powerful and tragic novel that deepened my appreciation of Japanese culture.

Kokoro, the novel’s title, is a complex and important word that can perhaps best be explained as “the thinking and feeling heart,” as distinguished from the workings of the pure intellect, devoid of human feeling.

...

“I finally couldn’t stand it anymore and said to him, ‘If there’s any fault in me, then please tell me honestly. If I can correct it, I will.’ And he replied, ‘You don’t have any fault. The fault is in me.’ When I heard that, it made me unbearably sad. It made me cry. And I longed more than ever to know how I might be to blame.”

Woman that she was, my mother’s reasoning grew rather incoherent at such times, though when it came to talking, she could easily outdo my father and me combined.

a commonplace idea stated with passionate conviction carries more living truth than some novel observation expressed with cool indifference.

In my heart, though, I was saddened that the person I loved and trusted most in the world could not understand me. But it’s within your power to help her understand, I thought, and yet you’re too cowardly to do so, and I grew still sadder.

entry.title: Models Behaving Badly by Emmanuel Derman
entry.content:
I can understand why so many people didn’t like the book: I picked it up expecting an interesting discussion about quantitative modelling, its drawbacks, etc – a fair expectation given the author’s other book My Life as a Quant – but only the last third of the book conforms to that expectation. It’s valuable to clarify the distinction between a model and a theory and to set the issue in its philosophical context, but I think that Derman takes it a little bit too far with the Judaic traditions and Spinoza’s ethics (the latter of which takes up a good chunk of the book). The anecdotes often have a tangential (at best) relation to the underlying theme of the book, and it seems like a case of the editors not standing up to the author.

However, the last third of the book is very good – a great discussion on typical failures (especially when physicists try their hand at finance), and how there needs to be a philosophical sea change for there to be progress. He likens some of the models in finance to the Greek tale of Pygmalion: a sculptor who creates a statue of a woman so beautiful that he falls in love with it (except in the real world there’s no Aphrodite to make the model come to life). And I can’t resist the little digs at the social sciences:

Highlights

The United Sates has suffered […] taxpayer-funded bailouts of large capitalist corporations; crony capitalism; private profits and public losses; companies that shorted stock for a living being legally protected from the shorting of their own stock; compromised yet unpunished ratings agencies; government policies that tried to cure insolvency by branding it as illiquidity.

...

We have all committed acts that surprise us and are hard to forgive. You can count yourself lucky if your model of yourself survives collision with time.

...

When someone proposes a theorem “Why?” is less important. A model is the construction of an analogy. A theory is the linking of the outer with the inner.

Phenomenology rather than theory

...

Pygmalion: a statue of a woman so beautiful that he fill in love with it. This is not an uncommon occurrence in the world of finance.

...

Soon I began to believe it was possible to apply the methods of physics successfully to economcics and finance, perhaps even to build a grand unified theory of securities. After twenty years on Wall Street I’m a disbeliever.** ****The similarity between physics and finance lies more in their syntax than their semantics.**

...

Converting their failed attempts at systematic stock price prediction into a fundamental postulate of their field was a fiendishly clever jujitsu response on the part of economists [in reference to the EMH].

...

“Physics models begin with the current state of the world and evolve it into the future. Financial models begin with current perceptions about the future and use them to move back into the present to estimate current values”.

entry.title: Moonwalking with Einstein by Joshua Foer
entry.summary: Memory palaces are effective
entry.content:
Moonwalking with Einstein is an autobiographical wrapper around the method of loci, i.e. memory palaces (popularised in BBC’s Sherlock ). We follow the inspirational (if clichéd) transformation of the author – from an ’ordinary journalist’ to a World Memory champion, just by using simple memory techniques. That may sound like clickbait, but the method of loci has been around for thousands of years. Supposedly, the phrase “in the first place” is a linguistic artefact of how orators would use the method of loci to remember speeches.

At a high level, the method of loci involves the attachment of pieces of information to locations – people tend to have far better visuospatial memory than verbal memory, possibly as a result of our need to navigate the Savannahs.

I went through a mind palaces phase, so can attest firsthand that they can dramatically improve recall. There are things that I put into a mind palace in 2016 that I can still clearly see (despite visiting the mind palace very infrequently). This brings me to the catch. Mind palaces aren’t a free lunch: a huge amount of mental effort and creativity are required to generate and ‘visit’ the imagery (which must be vivid and flashy by design). As the author notes, this can leave you a little bit wearied. But as I said, I’ve personally been able to retain the information without ‘visiting’ the images too often, so perhaps the initial input of mental effort is a worthwhile investment.

Although the book is a little bit unfocused, jumping from biography to discussion of the method of loci to interviews with people like Tony Buzan (surprisingly unpleasant!), some of the tangents are well worth the time.

I would recommend this book to anyone who is unfamiliar with the method of loci – if you haven’t tried it before, it’s worth giving it a go! Most likely you’ll realise that it’s difficult and possibly not worth the effort, but there’s a small chance that it’ll be a game-changer. Although I was familiar with mind palaces, I guess this book has reminded me of their power, so I will probably be doing some mental renovations in the next few weeks.

Highlights

Monotony collapses time; novelty unfolds it. You can exercise daily and eat healthily and live a long life, while experiencing a short one.

...

The best way to get out of the autonomous stage and off the OK plateau, Ericsson has found, is to actually practice failing. One way to do that is to put yourself in the mind of someone far more competent at the task you’re trying to master, and try to figure out how that person works through problems.

...

top achievers tend to follow the same general pattern of development. They develop strategies for consciously keeping out of the autonomous stage while they practice by doing three things: focusing on their technique, staying goal-oriented, and getting constant and immediate feedback on their performance.

...

the more you know, the easier it is to know more. Memory is like a spiderweb that catches new information. The more it catches, the bigger it grows. And the bigger it grows, the more it catches.

O(N^2) growth, as is the goal of my second brain.

entry.title: Narconomics by Tom Wainwright
entry.content:
Narconomics is an insightful and entertaining book which analyses the South American drug trade from an economic perspective, treating cartels as complex multinational corporations. When framed this way, it is clear that cartels have to deal with the same problems as other big companies: unhappy workers, public opinion, competition, diversification etc.

Narconomics is rightly critical of current government efforts to combat drugs. For example, their main approach is to target the supply side such that price increases (so hopefully demand decreases). This fails on two counts - drug demand is quite inelastic, but in any case targeting supply doesn’t seem to affect the price: the cartels just push the burden onto the farmers who are already living on pennies.

Super interesting stuff, and a quick read.

Policy failures

no analyst of the beef industry would calculate the price of a live steer mooching around on the Argentine pampa using restaurant data from New York City. Yet this is effectively how the value of heroin seized in Afghanistan [is valued]

• • •

there is an overwhelming focus on suppressing the supply side of the business, when basic economics suggests that addressing demand would make more sense. Cutting supply has done more to raise prices than it has to reduce the amount of drugs consumed, resulting in a more valuable criminal market.

• • •

In sum, by trebling the price of cocaine’s raw ingredient in South America—something no policy has yet gotten close to achieving—the best-case scenario is that cocaine’s retail price in the United States would rise by 0.6 percent. This does not seem like a good return on the billions of dollars invested in disrupting the supply of leaves in the Andes.

• • •

Governments are approaching the cocaine market as if it were the chocolate market, in which a rise in the price of cocoa beans leads to a corresponding rise in the price of chocolate bars. In reality, it is more like the art market, in which the tiny cost of the raw materials is insignificant compared with the high price of the finished product. Attempts to raise the price of cocaine by forcing up the cost of coca leaves is a bit like trying to drive up the price of art by raising the cost of paint.

• • •
Interesting economics

whereas Mexican gangbangers are highly footloose, liable to change sides to work for whichever cartel seems to be stronger or higher paying, the labor market for Salvadoran mareros is completely illiquid. With no chance whatsoever of one gang poaching the other’s employees, the maras have no need to compete for talent, which allows them to keep their wages low.

• • •

Jails provide a place to hire and train new members of staff, something that is normally extremely difficult for criminal organizations

• • •

Herschel Grossman, an American economist, created a model of mafia-provided public services and found that in some cases, competition between the state and the mob could result in public services that were better than those offered when the state alone provided them.

• • •

“The suppression of competition is a near-universal dream of established entrepreneurs. The mafia is one of the few non-governmental institutions that can help accomplish this goal.”

• • •

The vast increase in spending on border security has inadvertently transformed the people-smuggling business from an optional, cheap, amateur affair into a near-compulsory, very expensive, and cartel-dominated one. It is a gift to organized crime.

Regulation helps incumbents! See The Myth of Capitalism

• • •

most of the evidence suggests that demand for drugs is inelastic.

• • •

For criminals looking for an offshore base in the Americas, Guatemala has a lot to offer. But it faces stiff competition from its southern neighbor, Honduras. Guatemala arguably leads the way in terms of its slack labor market and dysfunctional state, but Honduras can claim an edge in a factor that is perhaps even more valuable to organized crime: accommodating government.

• • •
Suggestions

predicting the cartels’ next steps, and making sure that the money and lives laid down to stop them are not wasted, is easier when we recognize that they are run like other big multinational companies.

• • •

Making jails safer removes prisoners’ need for protection; providing training gives them noncriminal options when they eventually leave. The more the state fails to meet prisoners’ basic needs, the greater the opportunity for criminal gangs to fill the gap.

• • •
Misc

“We have to learn from the United States. There, drugs are moved around, the wholesale trade goes on, money is laundered—and nothing happens,” he says. “But the day someone kills a policeman, they mobilize the force of the state.

• • •

Persuasion takes the traditional form of plata o plomo—“silver or lead,” meaning a bribe or a bullet—which the gangs use to get their way in other areas of public life.

• • •

entry.title: Positioning by Al Ries
entry.content:
Positioning is quite an old book, and its age does show (at the time of writing, cable TV was the next big thing). So it’s hard to judge the extent to which the lessons of the book are still applicable because internet advertising has obviously changed things a lot.

However, I think the core ideas of Positioning are relatively timeless in the field of marketing. The main takeaway is that positioning should guide the entire market strategy: it is not some minor technique you can apply to try to improve your results, it is the only way of making your product stand out in a world where customers are deluged by choice.

I was intrigued by the suggestion that it is rarely a good idea to try to become the market leader if you’re not one already, because their position is likely strongly ingrained. You need to “climb the positioning ladder” one step at a time, focusing on getting to second place first, then biding your time before a strike at first. This is why positional thinking is still underused – it requires compromise and modesty. You will have to sacrifice some of your market share in order to build your position (the example he uses is Nyquil – paracetamol which marketed itself for night time only).

Positioning theory

Positioning is thinking in reverse. Instead of starting with yourself, you start with the mind of the prospect. Instead of asking what you are, you ask what position you already own in the mind of the prospect.

• • •

The essence of positioning is sacrifice. You must be willing to give up something in order to establish that unique position.

• • •

This is the classic mistake made by the leader. The illusion that the power of the product is derived from the power of the organization. It’s just the reverse. The power of the organization is derived from the power of the product, the position that the product owns in the prospect’s mind.

• • •

If you try to be all things to all people, you wind up with nothing. Better to narrow the focus of your expertise. To establish a unique position as a specialist, not as a jack-of-all-trades generalist.

• • •

With rare exceptions, a company should almost never change its basic positioning strategy. Only its tactics, those short-term maneuvers that are intended to implement a longterm strategy.

• • •

That’s why if you have a truly new product, it’s often better to tell the prospect what the product is not, rather than what it is. The first automobile, for example, was called a “horseless” carriage, a name which allowed the public to position the concept against the existing mode of transportation.

Via negativa

• • •
Competition

To win the battle for the mind, you can’t compete head-on against a company that has a strong, established position. You can go around, under or over, but never head to head. The leader owns the high ground. The No. 1 position in the prospect’s mind. The top rung of the product ladder. To move up the ladder, you must follow the rules of positioning. In our overcommunicated society, the name of the game today is positioning

• • •

“We’re better than our competitors” isn’t repositioning. It’s comparative advertising and not very effective.

• • •

people sometimes expect too much of an idea. They want one that is not only great, but one that everyone else thinks is great too. There are no such ideas. If you wait until an idea is ready to be accepted, it’s too late. Someone else will have preempted it.

It will always feel uncomfortable

• • •
Naming

Shakespeare was wrong. A rose by any other name would not smell as sweet.

• • •

When you have a generic brand name, you can afford to ignore the brand and promote the category.

• • •

In a physical sense, the name is also like the point of a knife. It opens up the mind to let the message penetrate. With the right name, the product fills the creneau and stays there.

• • •

Line-extension names are forgettable because they have no independent position in the mind. They are satellites to the original brand name. Their only contribution is to blur the position occupied by the original name. Often with catastrophic results.

a word has no meaning until someone uses it and fills it with meaning.

Jeff Lawson (Twilio CEO) recommends using a brand new word for a brand name – you get to completely shape its meaning

• • •

There is only negative equity in a bad name. When the name is bad, things tend to get worse. When the name is good, things tend to get better.

• • •
Organisational aspects

successful positioning program requires a major long-term commitment by the people in charge.

• • •

The essence of a good positioning strategy is that it transcends every aspect of a company. You know you have a winner when you run it up the corporate flagpole and everybody salutes.

• • •
Misc

The medium may not be the message, but it does seriously affect the message. Instead of a transmission system, the medium acts like a filter.

• • •

Messages would “sound better” in print if they were designed for radio first. Yet we usually do the reverse.

• • •

It’s bad enough when someone tries to take your position away. It’s tragic when you do it to yourself.

• • •

In dealing with media, you must conserve your anonymity until you are ready to spend it. And then when you spend it, spend it big.

• • •

The truth is, the road to fame and fortune is rarely found within yourself. The only sure way to success is to find yourself a horse to ride. It may be difficult for the ego to accept, but success in life is based more on what others can do for you than on what you can do for yourself.

The 48 Laws of Power, #7 - Get Others to Do the Work for You, but Always Take the Credit

• • •

Creativity by itself is worthless. Only when it is subordinated to the positioning objective can creativity make a contribution.

• • •

entry.title: Spring Snow by Yukio Mishima
entry.content:
Spring Snow is a subdued masterpiece. It doesn't feel very much like any of the other Japanese novels I’ve read. Mishima doesn’t rely on linguistic austerity like Murakami, and doesn’t need to try hard to create the bleak existentialist mood that permeates many Japanese works. In fact, Spring Snow for the most part feels very Western, which is fitting, because one of the main thematic undercurrents is the influence of westernisation in Meiji’s Japan. I am again struck by how much Japan’s cultural identity is related to its recent history, particularly the forceful transition from the Tokugawa Shogunate to the Meiji Empire. This seems to be an overarching backdrop to many of the Japanese novels that I have read (see Kokoro) – Spring Snow is no exception.

The novel itself is a rather tragic story of an intelligent, cultured, and attractive young man named Kiyoaki, and his affair with his beautiful childhood friend Satoko. It is not, however, a romance novel. I can’t exactly say what it is, but I know that it is lyrical, thoughtful, philosophical at times, but always brimming with beautiful melancholy.

don’t you think that would be marvelous? To take your own ideal and bend the world to it

Having gained the moon, how much then would he dread life in a world without it.

...

He could say: “No, let’s not go back.” But to do that was to reach out and pick up the dice. And his unskilled hand would have frozen at the very touch of them. He was not ready.

...

Those who lack imagination have no choice but to base their conclusions on the reality they see around them. But on the other hand, those who are imaginative have a tendency to build fortified castles they have designed themselves, and to seal off every window in them.

Every show of feeling was now governed with a marvelous economy. If a candle has burned brilliantly but now stands alone in the dark with its flame extinguished, it need no longer fear that its substance will dissolve into hot wax.

I’ve known supreme happiness, and I’m not greedy enough to want what I have to go on forever. Every dream ends. Wouldn’t it be foolish, knowing that nothing lasts forever, to insist that one has a right to do something that does?

The path we’re taking is not a road, Kiyo, it’s a pier, and it ends someplace where the sea begins. It can’t be helped.”

Beautiful acceptance of finiteness.

...

Just let matters slide. How much better to accept each sweet drop of the honey that was Time, than to stoop to the vulgarity latent in every decision. However grave the matter at hand might be, if one neglected it for long enough, the act of neglect itself would begin to affect the situation, and someone else would emerge as an ally.

entry.title: Sputnik Sweetheart by Haruki Murakami
entry.content:
I think I may have misunderstood Murakami. My notes on Norwegian Wood include the fantastically militant line: “he’s just trying to appeal to a semi-literate hipster audience”. So either I was wrong then, or I have joined the semi-literate hipster circle because I am starting to really enjoy Murakami.

Sputnik Sweetheart is written from the point of view of an introverted, intelligent young man who recounts the story of his friend Sumire and her relationship with Miu, an attractive older woman. Something happens to Sumire, and the narrator’s subsequent investigations are the heart of the novel. However, as is Murakami’s way, the turn of events is not exactly logical. Thus at the climax of the novel, the Ferris wheel scene, I was tempted to scoff and say “typical Murakami” – a completely unpredictable and perhaps even ridiculous twist.

It doesn’t make any sense, at all. Every potential resolution in the plot leads to another unanswered/unanswerable question. This is what I experienced with After Dark and Norwegian Wood – extremely engaging reads which ultimately left me unsatisfied because of the lack of a denouement. But I am beginning to appreciate the artistry underlying this indeterminacy. There is value in the somewhat arbitrary turns of events, a value increased by the undecidable nature of some of the questions put forward by Murakami.

It made her think of Laika, the dog. The man-made satellite streaking soundlessly across the blackness of outer space. The dark, lustrous eyes of the dog gazing out the tiny window. In the infinite loneliness of space, what could the dog possibly be looking at?

...

we were wonderful traveling companions but in the end no more than lonely lumps of metal in their own separate orbits. From far off they look like beautiful shooting stars, but in reality they’re nothing more than prisons, where each of us is locked up alone, going nowhere.

entry.title: Street Fighting Mathematics by Sanjoy Mahajan
entry.content:
The core goal of Street Fighting Mathematics is to help the reader make back-of-the-envelope approximations using techniques like dimensional analysis. In other words, it’s a written reference for the kind of simple mathematical tools that physicists end up being quite good at.

The first few chapters, which outline dimensional analysis, are indeed useful and interesting. But it quickly goes downhill as the author tries to find enough content to fill a textbook with. There are many examples where the author obviously sticks a rabbit into a hat (”1/4 is close enough to 1/2pi”) then expects you to be impressed when the rabbit pops out later ("our answer is, in fact, exact!!!!"). In essence, this book will teach you the art of reverse-engineered hand-wavy solutions.

If you’ve studied university physics, this will be a poor re-telling of things that are second nature to you. Otherwise, it’s worth reading the first few chapters but quickly putting the book away after that.

entry.title: The Financial Times Guide to Business Numeracy by Leo Gough
entry.content:
I had extremely low expectations for this book, but it’s actually a rather good overview of some nice mathematical techniques that may be applicable in business. It covers the surface of quite a wide range of important topics, such as statistics, decision analysis using game theory, time series analysis, and a rough overview of quantitative methods in financial markets.

Of course, not much explanation or detail is provided, but it's often useful to have a non-technical survey before you decide what merits further study. One of the things that I found most interesting was using Network Analysis to plan big projects – essentially, you construct directed acyclic graphs of all the tasks so you know what to prioritise.

Not a bad book to flick through during a commute!

entry.title: The (Mis)Behavior of Markets by Benoit Mandelbrot
entry.content:
Mandelbrot is primarily known for his contributions to fractal geometry and his eponymous Mandelbrot set, but as it happens, he was also a talented physicist and economist. I wasn’t expecting too much from this book, perhaps the stereotypical arrogant physicist trying to apply something he learnt in his lecture room to make money on the markets. But it doesn’t seem that Mandelbrot went out of his way to apply fractals to finance, it’s just that he saw that fractals could explain the largest body of facts with the fewest number of assumptions – the general goal of a scientific theory.

His scientific perspective on markets was delightfully refreshing: instead of a million shades of grey, Mandelbrot simply delineates a lot of claims into either ‘true’, ‘plausible’, or ‘false’. And it is both entertaining and enlightening to see how much of standard financial theory he dumps in the last category. The first give chapters are a lucid refresher of the tenets of academic finance (CAPM, random walks etc), after which he systematically demolishes the underlying assumptions. He then proposes his alternatives, which are logically accountable – every step and assumption can be scrutinised.

I think the book is best read after being indoctrinated (as I had been) by the Efficient Markets Hypothesis and its supporters. A Random Walk Down Wall Street was the first book that changed the way I thought about finance; I suppose you could call it a financial paradigm shift (in the spirit of Kuhn). The Misbehaviour of Markets must be the second. When people ask me for stock advice (it happens…) I normally revert to “stick your money in an ETF’”(while caveating that it’s not financial advice, of course). Certainly not a terrible suggestion, but in light of this book, it is not the be-all and end-all as I once thought it to be. There are opportunities for money to be made, perhaps in compensation for risks far greater than what traditional theory acknowledges.

In any case, notwithstanding my prosaic description, the book is a very good read. Mandelbrot writes well, with just the right amount of personal interludes (he is an interesting character!). He reminds me, in a way, of Richard Feynman. Honest, logical, and unwilling to follow doctrine if there is logical evidence against it – confident in what he knows to be wrong, but humble and self-critical in what he proposes to be true. An embodiment of the spirit of science.

Highlights

The odds of financial ruin in a free, global-market economy have been grossly underestimated. In this sense, the common man is wise in his prejudice that—especially after the collapse of the Internet bubble—markets are risky. But financial theorists are not so wise.

...

Warren E. Buffett, the famously successful investor and industrialist, jested that he would like to fund university chairs in the Efficient Market Hypothesis, so that the professors would train even more misguided financiers whose money he could win.

...

to be able to imitate reality is a form of understanding,

The importance of realistic simulations

...

A sculptor, when modeling in stone or clay, does not try to clone Nature; he highlights some things, ignores others, idealizes or abstracts some more, to achieve an effect. Different sculptors will seek different effects. Likewise, a scientist must necessarily pick and choose among various aspects of reality to incorporate into a model.

Modelling cannot be free from human bias – almost by definition. Otherwise who would be doing the modelling?

...

according to Pareto’s formula, the conditional probability of making a billion dollars once you have made half a billion is the same as that of making a million once you have made half a million. Money begets money, power makes power.

...

the Efficient Market Hypothesis is no more than that, a hypothesis. Many a grand theory has died under the onslaught of real data.

...

Our alien, seeing a planet obsessed by so illogical a system, quickly decamps. But his observation of two forms of wildness remain: abrupt change, and almost-trends. These are the two basic facts of a financial market, the facts that any model must accommodate.

...

Until the study of finance advances, for the how and why we will each have to look to our own imaginations. ...

For now we have to settle with phenomenology

...

there is no puzzle to the equity premium. Real investors know better than the economists. They instinctively realize that the market is very, very risky, riskier than the standard models say.

...

But the turbulent markets of the past few decades should have taught us, at the least, that value is a slippery concept, and one whose usefulness is vastly over-rated.

...

entry.title: The Noise of Time by Julian Barnes
entry.summary: “Art is the whisper of history, heard above the noise of time”
entry.content:
The Noise of Time is a tragic historical fiction novel about the peculiar genius Shostakovich, who was undoubtedly talented, though not enough to pass unscathed through Russia’s tumultuous early 20th century. It captures his incessant, yet justified, fear in the face of Power – tyrants like Stalin, and arguably Khrushchev – who never saw the value of music beyond its use in controlling people.

Shostakovich himself, or at least the novel’s portrayal of him, reminds me in some ways of Dostoevsky’s Raskolnikov, minus the homicidal tendencies; constantly questioning his own courage and ultimately disappointing himself. He is quite a charming character (irrespective of his musical genius), and one can only imagine the artistic heights he might have reached had he been free to compose as he pleased. All he wanted to do was make music, but this was never enough. He had to endure public humiliation and censorship, and maybe worse, he was forced to become something he wasn’t. The thematic culmination of the novel is the following observation:

At times, the novel is slightly self-conscious – Julian Barnes gets a bit too carried away with trying to philosophise on art and music, with the Shostakovich of the novel sometimes acting as a mouthpiece for Barnes. However, given the eloquence of his arguments and the stunning clarity of his conclusions, this is forgivable. The Noise of Time touches on politics, history, and philosophy – masterfully wrapped in a heartfelt yet melancholic package.

Highlights

Nothing begins just like that, on a certain date at a certain place. It all began in many places, and at many times, some even before you were born, in foreign countries, and in the minds of others.

...

He was an introverted man who was attracted to extroverted women. Was that part of the trouble?

...

He had ended the symphony fortissimo and in the major. What if he has ended it pianissimo and in the minor? On such things might a life - might several lives - turn.

I am fascinated by the idea of Khrushchev and other Soviet administrators listening to classic music to judge whether it is sufficiently Soviet.

...

When truth-speaking became impossible - because it led to immediate death - it had to be disguised. In Jewish folk music, despair is disguised as dance. And so, truth’s disguise was irony. Because the tyrants ear is rarely tuned to hear it.

...

The natural progression of human life is from optimism to pessimism; and a sense of irony helps temper pessimism, helps produce balance, harmony.

...

Art is the whisper of history, heard above the noise of time

...

Music is immortal, music will always last and always be needed, music can say anything, music ... and so on. he stopped his ears while they explained to him the nature of his own art. He applauded their idealism. And yes, music might be immortal, but composers alas are not. They are easily silenced, and even more easily killed.

...

If you turned your back on irony, it curdled into sarcasm. And what good was it then? Sarcasm was irony which had lost its soul.

There is a difference between wit and sarcasm!

entry.title: The Nuremberg Trials by Ann Tusa, John Tusa
entry.content:
I am deeply fascinated by the idea of the Nuremberg Trials, and have been for quite a while. Can humans overcome their need for vengeance to give a fair trial to the defeated enemies, some of whom seem downright monstrous? Is ‘war crime’ an oxymoron? Does hate speech warrant the death penalty?

I was surprised to learn that out of the four Allied powers, only America pushed for a fair trial – Britain, France and Russia wanted summary executions, or at most show trials. To America’s credit, they insisted on a respectable trial with a firm legal basis. Whether their motives were completely pure (which the authors doubt) doesn’t matter to me. Even the defendants were humbled by the American emphasis on a fair trial, which of course was a courtesy seldom given by the defendants to their prisoners.

I liked the rich descriptions of the defendants and prosecutors: it reminds you that all of these characters were all human (despicable as some of them were). This was reassuring in some cases (seeing the prosecutors’ and certain judges’ commitment to the truth), and horrifying when it came to people like Kaltenbrunner and Goering. The book is balanced enough for the reader to find themself rooting for some of the defendants, like Hjalmar Schacht, the president of the Reichsbank, who was later sent to the concentration camps for his participation in a Hitler assassination attempt (he was later acquitted on all counts).

It was a bit disappointing in the end to see how politics influenced their sentences given by the judges. It was almost like a bidding war: the Russians wanted a death penalty, the French wanted 10 years, and they had to meet somewhere in the middle. The American Judge suggested an unnecessarily harsh punishment for one of the defendants just as a power play with the Russian representative, which is somewhat repulsive. One of the bizarre parts of the book is when the authors point out that nobody could really justify Admiral Doenitz’s 10-year sentence (even the judges), but sentenced he was. Nevertheless, the judges overall seem to have realised that they were basically defining the new field of international law, and acted with commensurate dignity and fairness.

Although the book is long and detailed, and perhaps a bit slow at some stages, I seldom found it to be dry. On the contrary, the text is full of wit:

This book represents what I think the study of history should be like: it offers a balanced and nuanced perspective on genuinely interesting events that have shaped the world.

Highlights

Did an international court have the right to examine a state’s treatment of its own citizens, however vile? The judges dodged a decision and instead rested their verdicts on crimes committed by Nazi forces in occupied territories.

A great example of just how groundbreaking the Trials were – International Law was a nascent area.

...

It has to prove that victors can so rise above the ordinary limitations of human nature as to be able to try fairly the foes they vanquished, by submitting themselves to the restraints of law

Something that few victors have done in the past.

...

This committee considered adding a further charge – that of causing the war itself – but they could not agree whether causing war was actually a crime in international law.

...

When discussing policy on official occasions Stalin always recommended that war criminals be given a judicial hearing before (inevitably) being shot.

...

If you are determined to execute a man in any case, there is no occasion for a trial; the world yields no respect to courts that are merely organized to convict.

...

The vast bulk of the archives remained undamaged – largely due ‘to the lack of understanding on the part of those who issued the orders of the professional psychology of archivists, who would rather eviscerate their own children than destroy the material entrusted to their charge.’

Don’t mess with archivists and librarians!

...

The Russians asked for a twelve day delay, their avowed reason being that their chief prosecutor, Rudenko, had malaria. As a Foreign Office official saw it, it was ‘malaria of the diplomatic variety’ – the plain truth was that the Russian case was not ready.

...

That four great nations, flushed with victory and stung with injury, stay the hand of vengeance and voluntarily submit their captive enemies to the judgement of the law is one of the most significant tributes that Power has ever paid to Reason.’

...

[One] cannot subscribe to the perverted reasoning that society may advance and strengthen the rule of law by the expenditure of morally innocent lives but that progress in law may never be made at the price of morally guilty lives.’

...

An unequalled depth of cynicism was touched by the authorities at Mauthausen in their official report for one day in March 1945 which noted that 203 people had died, at regular intervals, all of heart attacks and in alphabetical order.

There’s some incredibly dark comedy in this – see Ianucci’s ‘The Death of Stalin’.

...

Frank was a lapsed Old Catholic who announced his conversion to Roman Catholicism in prison. This conversion had resulted in a state of abject penitence which was not always theologically distinguishable from maudlin self-pity.

...

it became clear that Kesselring was, in Dean’s words, ‘a decent man according to his own standards’ but that ‘his standards were those of a murderer and a liar whenever any German military advantage could be gained.’

...

‘a man who commits crimes cannot plead as a defence that he committed them in uniform.’

...

entry.title: This Side of Paradise by F. Scott Fitzgerald
entry.summary: A quest for individualism in the Jazz Age
entry.content:
This Side of Paradise , one of Fitzgerald’s first novels, is a charming coming-of-age story that follows Amory, a thinly veiled Fitzgerald, as he navigates the shifting challenges of growing up in the Jazz Age.

One of the central themes is individualism: whether any of these characters can truly separate themselves from their surroundings. The novel offers a pessimistic view. Amory constantly questions whether his epigrams are truly insightful or merely recycled ideas masquerading as wisdom – by the end, he renounces them altogether. The novel suggests that no individual can escape the influence of their time. Eleanor, for instance, remarks that if she had been born 100 years later, she would have been able to better use her intellect instead of just searching for a suitor. Similarly, nobody from Amory’s generation can avoid the war, and Amory laments how it has crushed true individuality. The novel concludes with a socialist manifesto, yet one that remains optimistic about human progress.

The traditional coming-of-age realisations are handled well, such as when Amory recognises how difficult it is to be truly exceptional:

He also grapples with the tension between romanticism and practicality:

Though the plot is fairly conventional, the writing is engaging and at times experimental, with some chapters shifting from prose to drama. What the novel lacks in polish, it makes up for with dry humour and charm. In this way, it stands as an interesting contrast to Fitzgerald’s later work, like Gatsby.

Highlights

She had once been a Catholic, but discovering that priests were infinitely more attentive when she was in process of losing or regaining faith in Mother Church, she maintained an enchantingly wavering attitude.

...

"THE SLICKER”

  1. Clever sense of social values. 2. Dresses well. Pretends that dress is superficial— but knows that it isn't. 3. Goes into such activities as he can shine in. 4. Gets to college and is, in a worldly way, successful. 5. Hair slicked.

...

if you don't use heaven as a continual referendum for your ideas you'll find earth a continual recall to your ambitions.

...

No, I'm romantic—a sentimental person thinks things will last— a romantic person hopes against hope that they won't. Sentiment is emotional.

...

"Beauty and love pass, I know… . Oh, there's sadness, too. I suppose all great happiness is a little sad. Beauty means the scent of roses and then the death of roses—"

...

"For this is wisdom—to love and live, To take what fate or the gods may give, To ask no question, to make no prayer, To kiss the lips and caress the hair, Speed passion's ebb as we greet its flow, To have and to hold, and, in time—let go."

...

Oh, Lord, what a pleasure it used to be to dream I might be a really great dictator or writer or religious or political leader— and now even a Leonardo da Vinci or Lorenzo de Medici couldn't be a real old-fashioned bolt in the world. Life is too huge and complex. The world is so overgrown that it can't lift its own fingers, and I was planning to be such an important finger"

...

the sentimental person thinks things will last—the romantic person has a desperate confidence that they won't."

...

Sacrifice by its very nature was arrogant and impersonal; sacrifice should be eternally supercilious.

...

Q.—What would be the test of corruption? A.—Becoming really insincere—calling myself "not such a bad fellow," thinking I regretted my lost youth when I only envy the delights of losing it.

...

Suddenly he felt an overwhelming desire to let himself go to the devil— not to go violently as a gentleman should, but to sink safely and sensuously out of sight.

entry.title: What is Life? by Erwin Schrodinger
entry.summary: Life is a rage against the second law of thermodynamics
entry.content:
Schrödinger’s contributions to physics are beyond question – he gave us a new language to describe the behaviour of the quantum objects. But physicists often have a spotty track-record of applying physics to other domains. I thus approached What is Life with a healthy skepticism.

But throughout the book, Schrödinger’s humility comes through strongly – a rare trait for physicists when discussing biology. His application of physics-based reasoning manages to justify some facts of biology, while highlighting uncharted territory.

As an example, he starts with the somewhat odd question “why is the human body so much bigger than an atom” to expound core points such as whether physics can hope to quantify the behaviour of living systems. His answer: the highly ordered biological processes require a certain stability that does not exist at smaller scales. However, we can’t just apply classical statistical physics and hope for the best because the parts that make a difference are actually small enough where quantum effects might make a difference – combined with the many biological feedback loops, this makes biology somewhat intractable from the physicist’s perspective.

Perhaps the most surprising thing is that he actually does provide an answer to the book’s eponymous question: what is life? Schrodinger believes that life is something that consumes negative entropy (i.e. order) to stave off its own inevitable decay into disorder. In his words, all living things have:

This is a wonderfully original perspective, and seems to be a useful model (though it raises interesting questions: to what extent is a computer alive?). On a side note, after reading this I had to read Asimov’s The Last Question again… the second law of thermodynamics is haunting.

Key ideas

  • The human body is, by necessity, many orders of magnitude larger than an atom. This is because such a highly ordered process requires a certain stability that does not exist at smaller realms. However, we can’t just apply statistical physics and hope for the best because the parts that make a difference are actually very small (small enough where quantum effects might make a difference).
  • Mutations must be sufficiently rare, otherwise evolution could not occur as any negative mutations would cancel out the effect of good mutations. This means that genes (large molecules) must have a certain resistance to isomeric change from ionising rays
  • Life consumes negative entropy to delay the inevitable thermodynamic equilibrium (death). Interesting suggestion that there is some relation between body temperature and 'intensity of life’.
    • Not sure this is rigorously a good definition, because by this analogy, fire (or a computer program) is alive
    • But it’s intuitively sensible

Highlights

A scientist is supposed to have a complete and thorough knowledge, at first hand, of some subjects and, therefore, is usually expected not to write on any topic of which he is not a master. This is regarded as a matter of noblesse oblige.

...

What is the characteristic feature of life? When is a piece of matter said to be alive? When it goes on 'doing something', moving, exchanging material with its environment, and so forth, and that for a much longer period than we would expect an inanimate piece of matter to 'keep going' under similar circumstances.

...

What an organism feeds upon is negative entropy. Or, to put it less paradoxically, the essential thing in metabolism is that the organism succeeds in freeing itself from all the entropy it cannot help producing while alive.

...

an engineer, familiar with heat engines only, will, after inspecting the construction of an electric motor, be prepared to find it working along principles which he does not yet understand.

...

An organism's astonishing gift of concentrating a 'stream of order' on itself and thus escaping the decay into atomic chaos of 'drinking orderliness' from a suitable environment seems to be connected with the presence of the 'aperiodic solids', the chromosome molecules, which doubtless represent the highest degree of well-ordered atomic association we know of much higher than the ordinary periodic crystal in virtue of the individual role every atom and every radical is playing here.

...

entry.title: When Genius Failed by Roger Lowenstein
entry.summary: “You can overintellectualize these Greek letters. One Greek word that ought to be in there is hubris.”
entry.content:
The story of LTCM reads like a Greek tragedy – specifically Oedipus Rex (minus the incest). It was a fund that had so much going for it: trading heavyweights, 1 billion in capital, and titans of financial mathematics (Nobel laureates Merton and Scholes). At the start, they were very successful, returning 50% annually and creating huge amounts of wealth. But nothing lasts forever. A perspective I liked was that these profits were really ‘borrowed against’ future losses – such is the nature of highly leveraged trading and negative-skew bets.

To paraphrase one commentator, you can analyse the greek letters (all of the mathematical terms in their models) as much as you want, but one Greek word not to forget about is hubris . Blinded by their success, LTCM started moving into strategies in which they had little expertise, thinking that their same models would work everywhere. They started making explicit directional bets on different markets, rather than sticking to their core arbitrage trades. In 1998, they were wiped out by the “black-swan” Russian debt crisis.

These are people who should have known better. There was serious evidence questioning the assumptions of the models at the time, but they traded all their chips as if there was not a chance that they could be wrong – completely ignoring the facts in exchange for elegant maths, and stacking on leverage and illiquidity risk.

I don’t think this story is damning for the field of quantitative finance as a whole, but it is a sobering reminder that markets are very difficult to model. An important counter-prescription:

Highlights

Rise

In a strict sense, there wasn’t any risk—if the world had behaved as it did in the past. —MERTON MILLER,

• • •

He wore the same blank half-tense expression when he won as he did when he lost. He had, I think, a profound ability to control the two emotions that commonly destroy traders—fear and greed—and it made him as noble as a man who pursues his self-interest so fiercely can be.

• • •

Long-Term’s profits were not, in a sense, all “earned”; in part, they were borrowed against the day when the cycle would turn. No investment—Internet wunderkinds included—can be judged on the basis of half a cycle alone.

• • •
Fall

Lured by the scent of the fantastic profits being earned in Greenwich, other banks were reaching for the same nickels as Long-Term. Inevitably, they whittled away the very spreads that had attracted them; thus do free markets punish success.

• • •

For men who prided themselves on being disciples of reason, their drive to live on the edge seemed inexplicable, unless they believed that becoming the richest would certify them as also being the smartest.

• • •

In times of trouble, markets become more closely linked, and seemingly unrelated assets rise and fall in tandem.

Correlations go to one

• • •

For a fund that had to lighten its load, the month had ended with the most nightmarish kind of bond market imaginable: no bond market at all.

• • •

One can be big (and therefore illiquid); one can (within prudent limits) be leveraged. But the investor who is highly leveraged and illiquid is playing Russian roulette, for he must be right about the market not merely at the end, but every single day.

• • •
Lessons

“You can overintellectualize these Greek letters,” Pflug reflected, referring to the alphas, betas, and gammas in the option trader’s argot. “One Greek word that ought to be in there is hubris.”

• • •

there is nothing wrong with being illiquid—unless you are vulnerable to being forced to sell in a hurry.

• • •

Though it is seldom realized, a creditor is also beholden to his debtor.

• • •

a reminder that foolishness carries a price would be no bad thing.

• • •

entry.title: Cat’s Cradle by Kurt Vonnegut
entry.content:
I think the problem with Cat’s Cradle was that the first time I read it, I was expecting science fiction. So I judged it for being poor scifi – “ice-nine” is a fascinating idea (a crystal of ice that turns any water it touches into ice), but its implications are hardly explored. If you look on Goodreads, more than 2000 people have shelved this book as science fiction. This is hugely misleading. Having read almost all of Vonnegut’s novels, I can't stress enough that Vonnegut isn’t a scifi writer (though he occasionally draws on elements of scifi).

With this out of the way, Cat's Cradle is brilliant. Bokononism, the fictional religion which plays a huge part of the book, is strangely charming. And it really counterbalances the other main melody of the book, that of ice-nine. I wish there were a proper copy of The Books of Bokonon , and I too want to know who is in my karass.

Cat’s Cradle is not the weirdest of Vonnegut's books (Breakfast of Champions still takes the cake there), but it’s certainly quirky. I can’t say whether it's better or worse than The Sirens of Titan or Slaughterhouse , but these three works together are enough for me to count Vonnegut as one of my favourite authors.

Highlights

“Tiger got to hunt, bird got to fly;

Man got to sit and wonder 'why, why, why?'

Tiger got to sleep, bird got to land;

Man got to tell himself he understand.”

...

She hated people who thought too much. At that moment, she struck me as an appropriate representative for almost all mankind..

...

“In the beginning, God created the earth, and he looked upon it in His cosmic loneliness.

And God said, "Let Us make living creatures out of mud, so the mud can see what We have done." And God created every living creature that now moveth, and one was man. Mud as man alone could speak. God leaned close to mud as man sat up, looked around, and spoke. Man blinked. "What is the purpose of all this?" he asked politely.

"Everything must have a purpose?" asked God.

"Certainly," said man.

"Then I leave it to you to think of one for all this," said God.

...

Each one of us has to be what he or she is.

...

“Beware of the man who works hard to learn something, learns it, and finds himself no wiser than before,” Bokonon tells us. “He is full of murderous resentment of people who are ignorant without having come by their ignorance the hard way.”

...

Let us start our Republic with a chain of drug stores, a chain of grocery stores, a chain of gas chambers, and a national game. After that, we can write our Constitution.

...

entry.title: Don Quixote by Miguel de Cervantes
entry.content:
Don Quixote is a very surprising novel. Despite its important role in Western literature (and the fact that it was written over 400 years ago) – Cervantes is often considered to be “Spanish Shakespeare” – Don Quixote is readable and often hilarious, with a charming immaturity (plenty of “Tom and Jerry”-esque scatological humour).

Sancho Panza’s dry wit makes him the perfect foil to Quixote, allowing the delusions to become a mirror for reality. The metafiction felt a bit silly initially, but it becomes delightfully complex as the novel progresses – especially impressive given that the concept of metafiction was still in its infancy at the time of Cervantes.

Quixote made up a fantasy world in which he was a knight. Cervantes' fictional historians made up stories about Quixote. And Cervantes himself? The great creator who cannot separate himself from his creation.

"God help us! The world is nothing but machinations and tricks quite opposite one to the other. I can do no more"

...

“When life itself seems lunatic, who knows where madness lies? Perhaps to be too practical is madness. To surrender dreams — this may be madness. Too much sanity may be madness — and maddest of all: to see life as it is, and not as it should be!”

...

“There were no embraces, because where there is great love there is often little display of it.”

...

“El que lee mucho y anda mucho, ve mucho y sabe mucho.”

“He who reads and journeys a lot, sees a lot and knows a lot” (my translation)

entry.title: The Brothers Karamazov by Fyodor Dostoevsky
entry.content:
Dmitri Karamazov often invokes the name of Claude Bernard as an insult for those he deems too rationalistic or materialistic. Interestingly, Bernard was acquainted with Emile Zola; many consider this duo to be the pioneers of the Naturalist movement of literature.

In many ways, TBK is a Naturalist novel. Dostoevsky proceeds in an extremely logical way, introducing the test subjects (the brothers and the father), the rich cultural backdrop that Russia provides, and the stimuli. A key piece of this is Ratikin, a somewhat unusual character. He plays a minor role, which he is remarkably bitter about (almost breaking the fourth wall) but nevertheless synthesises a remarkably lucid “hypothesis” regarding the futures of the brothers (and father) Karamazov. Dostoevsky artfully switches between the role of “creator” of the narrative, and Naturalist “discoverer” – at times it feels like he, along with the reader, is trying to piece together the facts.

But classifying TBK as purely a Naturalist novel, and thereby saying that one of its main intentions is to see how characters react under abnormal circumstances, would be an injustice. It is not just the reactions of the characters that are being examined, but their whole internal dialogues and flittering interactions of their different character traits, and more specifically how they rationalise the situation to fit with their worldview.

Some themes/motifs that came across from TBK :

  • The search for truth. Superficially regarding the trial, but more specifically regarding how each of the characters is looking for the true motivation to live.
  • The idea of confession before the general public as being the ultimate catharsis.
  • Inheritance, not just financially, but also in the sense that all (four?) of the brothers contain the seed of a Karamazov.

Book V: Pro and Contra really stood out – Ivan’s speeches are works of art in themselves. Chapter 4: Rebellion is thoughtful (if horrific), and has certainly left its mark on literature – Ursula Le Guin’s The Ones Who Walk Away From Omelas draws heavily from it. The Grand Inquisitor is a must-read for Christians and Atheists alike – it is an analysis and cross-examination of the Temptation of Christ, and is pure art. The highlights of TBK for me are probably Book V, Zosima’s homilies, and Ivan’s meeting with the Devil.

It is hardly surprising that TBK is so highly respected by many world leaders. This would probably be my favourite book if I understood it better. Well worth the ~800 pages, and criminally due a re-read.

Misc notes

  • Written from a nonstandard point of view, as if Dostoevsky himself is trying to piece together the facts (though obviously he has access to a lot more information).
  • It's almost like a theatre piece: he sets up the stage by introducing the characters and a situation. Can't help but be reminded of Zola's 'natural experiments'.
  • Such fantastic digressions, which allow Dostoevsky to speak through his characters (e.g when Ivan was giving his views on the church and state).
  • Rakitin is a bit of an unusual character. He plays a minor role, which he is remarkably bitter about (fourth wall eh?) but nevertheless synthesises a remarkably lucid prophesy regarding the futures of the brothers (and father) Karamazov. However this is a bit contradictory with his seemingly optimistic views on mankind (at least in relation to those of Ivan): “Mankind will find strength in itself to live for virtue, even without believing in the immortality of the soul”. Whether this statement proves true remains to be seen – will any of the brothers live in virtue after conceding the nonexistence of the soul? (I’m looking at you Alexei).
  • A motif seems to be the brothers’ ‘inheritance’, but money isn’t all that they have received from their father – they give in to the inner Karamazov.
  • Interesting how Ivan uses his of mathematics to justify that he has no right to pretend to understand God.
  • Book V: Pro and Contra is amazing. Ivan’s speeches are works of art.
    • I adore Ivan’s use of the term ‘Euclidean mind’ in the end of Chapter 3
    • Chapter 4: Rebellion. Ivan's conclusions about torturing children are quite horrific. ‘The Ones who Walk Away from Omelas’ borrows its central idea from one of Ivan’s points.
    • Chapter 5: The Grand Inquisitor. A must read for Christians. An analysis and cross-examination of the temptation of christ, which is the work of genius.
  • The elder Zosima has some thoughts that are remarkably reminiscent of Ivan's, especially regarding the torture of children. Strange how two individuals with such different paradigms can come to same conclusions. Contributes to the theme of 'interpretation of facts'?
  • Truly terrifying when Ivan's cynical exterior breaks and reveals his inner torments. Noteworthy how the devil seems not at all different to Ivan.
  • A recurring idea is that of an individual coming clean before and thence being judged by their peers:
    • Lise wants everyone to know her evil thoughts
    • The young Zosima convinces that dude to throw everything away and confess to his murders
    • Ivan wants to let his reputation burn for no obvious gain at the trial,
  • The judge seems to shadow Dostoevsky: "an educated and humane man with a practical knowledge of his task. [...]. He was concerned with the phenomenon, its classification, seeing it as a product of our social principles, as characteristic of the Russian element". Also another reminder of Naturalism.
  • But this is so much more than naturalism, it's not testing how the characters react but how their characteristics, their internal dialogues, their psyche.

Highlights

(I would have highlighted much more had I read it on my kindle!)

The Karamazov inheritance

"A brazen face and a Karamazov conscience"

• • •

“Because I’m a Karamazov. Because when I fall into the abyss, I go straight into it, head down and heels up, and I’m even pleased that I’m falling in just such a humiliating position, and for me I find it beautiful.” - Dmitri

• • •

“The same insect lives in you [Alexei] and stirs up storms in your blood. Storms, because sensuality is a storm, more than a storm! Beauty is a fearful and terrible thing! Fearful because it’s undefinable, and it cannot be defined, because here God gave us only riddles.”

• • •

"They have their Hamlets, but so far we only have Karamazovs".

• • •

“We are of a broad, Karamazovian nature […] capable of containing all possible opposites and of contemplating both abysses at once, the abyss above us, an abyss of lofty ideals, and the abyss beneath us, an abyss of of the lowest and foulest degradation.”

• • •
Book 5: Pro and Contra

“True, it’s a feature of the Karamazov, to some extent, this thirst for life despite all; it must be sitting in you, too; but why is it base? There is still an awful lot of centripetal force on our planet, Alyosha. I want to live, and I do live, even if it be against logic. Though I do not believe in the order of things, still the sticky little leaves that come out in the spring are dear to me, the blue sky is dear to me, some people are dear to me, whom one loves sometimes, would you believe it, without even knowing why”. - Ivan, V.3

Ratikin’s prophesy: “Mankind will find strength in itself to live for virtue, even without believing in the immortality of the soul”.

• • •

"I once knew a young lady still of the last “romantic” generation who, after several years of enigmatic love for a certain gentleman, whom, by the way, she could have married quite easily at any moment, ended up, after inventing all sorts of insurmountable obstacles, by throwing herself on a stormy night into a rather deep and swift river from a high bank somewhat resembling a cliff, and perished there decidedly by her own caprice, only because she wanted to be like Shakespeare’s Ophelia."

• • •

“I have a Euclidean mind, an earthly mind, and therefore it is not for us to resolve things that are not of this world." - Ivan, V.3

• • •

“It’s still possible to love one’s neighbour abstractly, and even occasionally from a distance, but hardly ever up close”

• • •

“People speak sometimes about the ‘animal’ cruelty of man, but that is terribly unjust and offensive to animals, no animal could ever be so cruel as a man, so artfully, so artistically cruel”.

• • •

“I think that if the devil does not exist, and man has therefore created him, he has created him in his own image and likeness”.

• • •

“For the mystery of man’s being is not only in living, but in what one lives for. Without a firm idea of what he lives for, man will not consent to live and will sooner destroy himself than remain on earth, even if there is bread all around him. "

Misc

"In most cases, people, even wicked people, are far more naive and simple-hearted than one generally assumes. And so are we."

Hanlon’s razor: never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by incompetence

• • •

"A socialist Christian is more dangerous than a socialist atheist."

• • •

"This is precisely what has tormented me all my life, that I thirsted for nobility, that I was, so to speak, a sufferer for nobility, seeking it with a lantern, Diogenes’ lantern, and meanwhile all my life I’ve been doing only dirty things,"

• • •

entry.title: Antifragile by Nassim Nicholas Taleb
entry.summary: With an antifragile hammer, everything looks like a fragile nail
entry.content:
Antifragile is NNT’s self-proclaimed magnum opus, tying ideas from The Black Swan and Fooled by Randomness into a unified framework. Accordingly, it has everything we’ve come to expect from NNT: a near-delusional sense of self-importance, frequent bitterness (admittedly, oftentimes humorous), some neat ideas, and a rampant overreaching of these ideas.

My belief is that there are important ideas and there are unimportant ideas, but there are no ideas so important that they explain everything. The world is far too complex for that. Yet when you have an antifragile hammer, everything in the world becomes a nail.

The book is about convexity and optionality. The core idea is that any time you have an asymmetric payoff, you want volatility – you benefit from disorder (and time) and are thus “antifragile”. This is an important idea: limited downside with uncapped upside is something we should seek both in investment and life – too many people focus on short term results without considering the entire distribution of outcomes that they are exposed to as a result of their decisions. But it’s also important to remember that options have a finite value – something which NNT seems to selectively ignore.

A significant chunk of the book involves Taleb abstracting his ideas of antifragility to the realm of medicine – given his lack of credentials in this area, I’m not sure this is warranted. He is staunchly against what he calls the “interventionist” philosophy of medicine and essentially abides by Nietzche: “what doesn’t kill me makes me stronger”. The advice seems occasionally sensible (avoid unnatural medication that promises small benefits in exchange for unknown/unknowable consequences, e.g thalidomide), but at other times he seems purposely belligerent, bordering on ignorant (e.g don’t use ice packs for swelling because there’s no evidence it works).

His discussion of “interventionism” extends beyond medicine to technology and society. The main premise is that natural things are good because they have survived the test of time (which is the ultimate destroyer of fragility). Frustratingly, Taleb concedes that some technology has been beneficial (and strongly praises Silicon Valley), but spends little time demarcating what makes some non-natural things good and others bad.

Another weird Talebism: NNT believes in exclusively(?) reading old books. His justification is the Lindy effect – the idea that the life expectancy of something is proportional to its age (if they are still relevant after so many years, they must be worth reading). My own thinking has slowly converged on this, e.g focussing on “evergreen” podcast content rather than current affairs podcasts, but I reject the extreme to which Taleb takes it. He suggests, for instance, that we should learn calculus by reading Principia Mathematica . A counterpoint: modern perspectives on old concepts are valuable because modern authors have the advantage of seeing how the concept is truly contextualised – in a way, this is as antifragile as the bottom-up villages in Switzerland that Taleb praises.

The main reason to read Antifragile is that (for better or worse) lots of pseudo-intellectuals have read it – it’s the kind of thing that could come up at a dinner party. But the concepts are semi-original at best, and while the writing style is occasionally entertaining, Taleb's pugnacity severely detracts from the book.

Key points

  • Burden of proof is on the interventionist
  • Prediction encourages fragility. There is a nice link to Dune here – Paul is careful to avoid over-reliance on his prescience so that he can be antifragile.
  • Time is the ultimate arbiter of fragility.
  • Past evidence rarely samples tails (positive or negative) – leading to people avoiding good things due to lack of evidence, or exposing themselves due to tails.
  • In any evolutionary system, if you don’t understand something, it probably serves a deeper purpose
    • Nietzche says it better: “What is not intelligible to me is not necessarily unintelligent”
    • But even here, NNT blindly takes this to the extreme, ignoring the reality that the true art is in understanding when something is truly vestigial.

Technicals

  • Estimation error should push probabilities to half
  • Probability matching is a hedge against changing probabilities
  • High earnings multiples may be explained by fat-tailed growth distributions

Taleb-isms:

  • Procrustean bed: Procrustes got people to fit perfectly into his bed by cutting or stretching their limbs. Corresponds to situations in which simplifications are not simplifications. (loc 7480)
  • Hormesis: small stressors are beneficial
  • Iatrogenics: Harm done by the healer, as when the doctor’s interventions do more harm than good. (loc 7495)
  • Lindy Effect: A technology, or anything nonperishable, increases in life expectancy with every day of its life.
  • Jensen’s inequality: difference between function of expectation and expectation of function

Highlights

Core thesis

Sensitivity to harm from volatility is tractable, more so than forecasting the event that would cause the harm. (loc 375)

We can estimate the sensitivity to tail events, but NOT the probability of the tail events

• • •

Crucially, if antifragility is the property of all those natural (and complex) systems that have survived, depriving these systems of volatility, randomness, and stressors will harm them. (loc 380)

• • •

In social policy, it consists in protecting the very weak and letting the strong do their job, rather than helping the middle class to consolidate its privileges, thus blocking evolution and bringing all manner of economic problems that tend to hurt the poor the most. (loc 3064)

A fantastic argument against socialism

• • •

we may never get to know x, but we can play with the exposure to x, barbell things to defang them; we can control a function of x, f(x), even if x remains vastly beyond our understanding. (loc 7448)

• • •

the non-natural needs to prove its benefits, not the natural—according to the statistical principle outlined earlier that nature is to be considered much less of a sucker than humans. In a complex domain, only time—a long time—is evidence. (loc 5982)

• • •

“What is not intelligible to me is not necessarily unintelligent” is perhaps the most potent sentence in all of Nietzsche’s century—and (loc 4554)

• • •
Economic fragility

The fragility of every startup is necessary for the economy to be antifragile (loc 1369)

• • •
